headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Matt, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today as we review our fourth quarter and full year 2015 results. With me on the call this morning are Ben Moreland, Crown Castle's Chief Executive Officer; and Jay Brown, Crown Castle'
componenttext:
Thank you, Matt, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today as we review our fourth quarter and full year 2015 results. With me on the call this morning are Ben Moreland, Crown Castle's Chief Executive Officer; and Jay Brown, Crown Castle's Chief Financial Officer. To aid the discussion, we have posted supplemental materials in the Investors section of our website at crowncastle.com, which we will refer to throughout the call this morning.
This conference call will contain forward-looking statements which are subject to certain risks, uncertainties and assumptions, and actual results may vary materially from those expected. Information about potential risk factors which could affect our results is available in the press release under Risk Factors sections of the company's SEC filings.
Our statements are made as of January 28, 2016, and we assume no obligations to update any forward-looking statements.
In addition, today's call includes discussions of certain non-GAAP financial measures. Tables reconciling these non-GAAP financial measures are available in the supplemental information package in the Investors section of the company's website at crowncastle.com.
With that, I will turn the call over to Jay.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Son, and good morning, everyone. As you saw from our release yesterday, the fourth quarter was another great quarter, bringing 2015 to a strong close and positioning us to raise our full year 2016 outlook. For the full year 2015, AFFO per share of
componenttext:
Thanks, Son, and good morning, everyone. As you saw from our release yesterday, the fourth quarter was another great quarter, bringing 2015 to a strong close and positioning us to raise our full year 2016 outlook. For the full year 2015, AFFO per share of $4.30 was up 8% compared to 2014, and our increased midpoint for full year 2016 outlook for AFFO per share of $4.68 represents a 9% increase compared to 2015.
In addition to delivering great results and extending our track record of execution, 2015 was marked by several significant accomplishments. During 2015, we achieved an investment-grade credit rating from each of S&P and Fitch ratings. Also during the year, we redeployed capital from the divestiture of our former Australian subsidiary to further grow and strengthen our leadership position in wireless infrastructure in the U.S., which we believe is the most attractive market for wireless investment.
Today, with our portfolio of approximately 40,000 towers and 16,000 miles of fiber supported small cell deployments. We are able to provide wireless carriers comprehensive solutions across the country as they continue to upgrade and enhance their networks to meet increasing consumer demand for mobile data.
Shifting to the fourth quarter results on Slide 4, site rental revenue grew 9% year-over-year from $723 million to $785 million, an increase of $62 million. The $62 million increase is comprised of $49 million of organic site rental revenue growth, less $17 million in adjustments for straight line accounting associated with contracted fixed rate escalation, plus $30 million in contributions from acquisitions, which primarily consisted of [indiscernible] and other adjustments. The organic site rental revenue growth of $49 [ph]  Million represents growth of 7% year-over-year comprised of approximately 10% growth from new leasing activity and cash escalations, net of approximately 3% in tenant nonrenewals.
Moving to Slide 5. Our fourth quarter results reflect rental gross margin adjusted EBITDA and AFFO exceeded the midpoint of our previously provided fourth quarter 2015 outlook.
Turning to investment activity, as shown on Slide 6. During the fourth quarter, we invested $251 million in capital expenditures, of which $29 million was sustaining capital expenditures and $222 million was discretionary investment. Included in our discretionary investment is approximately $23 million for land purchases. 
Our proactive approach to achieving long-term control of the ground beneath our sites is core to our business as we seek to control our largest operating expense and produce stable and growing cash flow over time. Today, 3/4 of our site rental gross margin generated from towers on land owned or controlled for more than 20 years. Where we have ground leases, the average term remaining on our ground leases is approximately 30 years. Of the remaining discretionary investments, we invested $199 million in revenue-generating capital expenditures consisting of $90 million on existing sites and $109 million on the construction of new sites, primarily small cell construction activity. Small cells continued to perform ahead of expectations and currently generate 12% of total site rental revenue and 11% of total site rental gross margin. Excluding the benefit from our recent acquisition of Sunesys, small cell site rental revenue grew approximately 30% year-over-year. 
Today, our small cell networks consist of approximately 17,000 nodes on air here or under construction supported by 16,000 miles of fiber. Of the 17,000 nodes miles, approximately 12,000 of the nodes are on air with the other approximately 5,000 nodes under construction and expected to be completed over the next 12 to 24 months. 
Continuing on to financing activities, during the quarter, we paid a quarterly common stock dividend of $0.885 per share or $295 million in the aggregate. For the full year 2015, we paid quarterly common stock dividend in aggregate of $3.345 per common share. Additionally, in January, we closed on a $5.5 billion senior unsecured credit facility. Proceeds from the new facility, together with cash on hand, were used to repay our previous senior secured credit facilities as of January 26 [ph], we have $1.6 billion of availability under our 5-year revolver. As a result of the refinancing, our senior unsecured notes were upgraded by S&P to investment grade.
Even more impactful than lowering the cost of debt, we believe that an investment-grade capital structure will ultimately drive down our cost of equity. Equally as important, we believe having access to a deeper pool of capital will result in a more stable, long-term cash flow and increased flexibility to pursue discretionary growth opportunities.
Moving on to the full year 2016 on Slide 7. We have increased our expectations at the midpoint for site rental revenues by $10 million, site rental gross margin by $7 million and adjusted EBITDA by $12 million and AFFO by $11 million. The increase in the outlook reflects the strong results from the fourth quarter, our continuing belief that 2016  leasing activities will be similar to 2015, and the timing benefit related to tenant nonrenewals occurring later than previously expected.
It is important to note that our overall expectations for the number of tenant nonrenewals in aggregate has remained unchanged. For more detailed information regarding our current book of contracted tenant leases, including our expectations for nonrenewals, those are available in our supplemental information package.
At the AFFO per share line, the updated midpoint of our full year 2016 outlook results to 9% growth year-over-year compared to 2015, increasing from $4.30 per share to $4.68 [ph] per share.
Like 2015, 2016 is shaking up to be another great year. We believe the essential elements for long-term shareholder value creation are attractive as they've ever been. We continue to see stable and consists leasing from our carrier customers. We have a run rate of attractive discretionary investment opportunities, primarily in the form of small cell to enhance and grow our business. And we have an opportunity to manage the cost of debt and lower the cost of equity as we transition to an investment-grade balance sheet. All of this gives us confidence in maintaining our long-term goal of delivering AFFO per share and dividend per share growth of 6% to 7% on an annual basis.
Before turning the call over to Ben, I'd like to take this moment to discuss the announced succession plan. I'm honored and excited to have the opportunity to lead the Crown Castle team. I've had the privilege of working with Ben over the last 17 years and he has been a great friend and mentor to me. Over the last 8 years, through Ben's leadership as CEO, we have grown the business significantly, increasing AFFO per share from $1.66 to $4.30 and have successfully doubled the size of our tower portfolio, established ourselves as the leader in small cell and strengthened our balance sheet, positioning us better than ever to capitalize on the to tremendous opportunities that lie ahead. I will benefit greatly in my new role by being surrounded by very talented and experienced executive team that has been instrumental in all of these accomplishments.
Together with the rest of the Crown Castle team, we are looking forward to continuing to execute on our strategy of driving long-term shareholder return through disciplined capital allocation, dividend growth and delivering for our customers. And with that, I'll turn it over to Ben.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jay, and thanks to all of you for joining us on the call this morning. Extra early. I'll touch on our success plan in a moment, but first I'd like to comment on 2015 results and what lies ahead. In short, we had a great year, exceeding our expecta
componenttext:
Thanks, Jay, and thanks to all of you for joining us on the call this morning. Extra early. I'll touch on our success plan in a moment, but first I'd like to comment on 2015 results and what lies ahead. In short, we had a great year, exceeding our expectations throughout the year and an executing on strategic actions through, the sale of our Australian and the purchase of the Sunesys fiber assets that really sets us up well to win in the future.
I want to thank my colleagues at Crown Castle for their hard work in delivering on our commitments in 2015. 
Now on to the future. As Jay just mentioned, we believe we have the essential elements from long-term shareholder value creation and they're as attractive as ever. I'd like to spend a few minutes to further elaborate on Jay's comments regarding each of these elements. These include: a continued healthy and sustained leasing environment over the next several years; a long runway of investment opportunities that we expect to drive high-quality long-term growth and all the while maintaining a strong balance sheet and managing risk appropriately to drive down the cost of capital. 
First, on leasing. We believe that we're in the midst of a multiyear wireless investment cycle that will result in a sustained level of leasing activity, similar to what we experienced in 2014 and 2015. And that is what we expect to see in 2016.
For 2016, we're expecting approximately $170 million in new leasing activity. Of which, $150 million -- $115 million will come from tower leasing. The $115 million in tower leasing represents a pace of adding approximately 1 tenant equivalent over a 10-year period on our 40,000 towers or 1/10 of a tenant per year per tower, which is approximately our average pace of annual leasing over the last 7 years. Importantly, through those 7 years, we've been through a number of different macroeconomic cycles and covered several different wireless investment cycles in terms of technology, level of engagement by carrier customers and different environments. Given the underlying long-term perspective of positive fundamentals, from the continued increase in mobile data consumption, we believe that this pace of leasing is a reasonable expectation for our future growth.
Industry research projects mobile data to increase sevenfold between 2014 and 2019, a compounded annual growth rate of 47% while roughly doubling every 2 years. Recently, some of the wireless carriers have recorded mobile data growth even higher in the range 60% to 75% per year growth during 2015. Against this backdrop, we expect the carriers to continue to invest on a consistent basis to maintain and improve network quality, which is a competitive necessity as carriers retain existing customers, attract new customers and monetize their networks through the development of new revenue streams, such as over-the-top video and telematics.
As a shared wireless infrastructure provider, Crown Castle stands ready to assist wireless carriers in this by providing them with quick cost-effective access to wireless infrastructure as they seek to upgrade and enhance their networks.
With our tower portfolio and small cell expertise, we have the unique capability to deliver across all means of shared infrastructure to meet the network needs of our carrier customers. Additionally, the run rate for our growth is further supported by the amount of spectrum that is expected to be deployed over the next several years, including a spectrum from last year's AWS3 auction, the spectrum from this year's anticipated broadcast incentive auction and the spectrum currently held by the carriers and others such as dish and FirstNet. 
Turning to capital allocation. When we evaluate various investment alternatives we have whether it's small cell, share purchases or acquisitions, our goal is to drive long-term growth and AFFO per share and dividend per share. By this measure, we are very excited by a recent and ongoing investment in small cells. To date, our $3 billion investment in small cells generates a yield of approximately 8%, inclusive of our initial $1 billion investment in NextG, the acquisition we did in 2012 with, an initial yield of approximately 3% to 4% and our continued greenfield investments.
We are underwriting new small cell builds with anticipated initial yield of 6% to 8% on the anchor tenant where we believe we have the opportunity to drive yields higher through co-location, with the second tenant expected to achieve low to mid teens yield and the expectation of further yield accretion when we add a third and fourth tenant in overtime.
On this front, in addition to the anchor tenant, we are seeing strong co-location demand on our small cell networks. We have focused our small cell efforts in the top 25 markets and believe that these early systems will be some of the most attractive locations in the future given their franchise value.  
Just like towers, the need for network densification is driving small cell growth. Given the challenges carriers space and bringing more capacity to many urban and suburban geographies, the need to get closer to the subscribers, and focused on resuing spectrum more efficiently, carriers are turning to small cells as a critical tool to improve their networks.
With a very similar business and economic model is our tower business. We see a long runway of attractive investment opportunities in small cells. 
Shifting to the balance sheet and risk profile. We view our dividend as a growing annuity paid to shareholders, while we effectively pass through the cash flow we generate from providing U.S. wireless carriers with access to mission-critical infrastructure. Our goal is to protect and grow the dividend stream over time. 
Our dividend is supported by long-term recurring contracted leases that we have in place, which currently represent approximately $20 billion of future contracted rent payments plus future growth from contracted rent escalators and a continuing wireless investments being made, as I mentioned. From this foundation, we are focused on managing financial and operating risk as we allocate capital and grow the business. 
On the balance sheet side, we believe maintaining an investment grade balance sheet should provide us with access to a deeper and more stable pool of capital, reducing risk to our cash flow and providing us with an increased flexibility to pursue potential investment opportunities, both of which are supportive of the securing growing dividend.  This bank perspective drives our capital allocation decisions as we continue to believe that the U.S. market provides us with the most attractive risk-adjusted return opportunities.
Bottom line, with the sustained level of leasing that we expect to continue over the next several years, the small cell opportunities still ahead of us, the strength of our balance sheet, and the quality of our business, we believe we can continue to deliver 6% to 7% AFFO per share and dividend growth per share. Further, we believe our expected growth rate combined with our current dividend yield of approximately 4.3% represents a very attractive long-term total return profile for shareholders.
Finally, I'd like to speak to our CEO succession plan that we announced last night. I began contemplating this and subsequently engaged the board in this conversation from time to go after on a number of considerations that led me to conclude that 2016 was the right time to begin this transition.
First, as we discussed on this call, the company is incredibly well positioned for this transition, having accomplished a number of strategic objectives that I believe are important to set us up for the next generation of market leadership and value creation. Including on this list would be assemblage of our unrivaled tower portfolio, the sale of our Australian business, the acquisition of Sunesys and leadership in the exciting small cell arena, and the strength in the balance sheet with the achievement of investment-grade rating late last year.
Second, Jay is ready, ready to step up. We worked together for 17 years since the early days of Crown Castle, and he has been an integral part of all we have accomplished. He has the trust and respect of the board, the executive team and the organization as well as the investment community.
I am very fortunate to have him as a successor and have absolute confidence that he is the right leader to lead the organization into this next chapter of success. Most importantly though, Jay will be leading a team of seasoned professionals who are very good at executing for customers across all our assets of towers and small cells. 
Finally, on a personal level, it's been an unbelievable privilege to lead Crown as CEO these last 8 years. I have always found it available from time to time to push myself out of my comfort zone in search of new challenges. Many years ago, I lost my dad to a heart attack when he was only 47. In 2014, my wife has a breast cancer scare before she was caught early has resulted in a full recovery. With our kids out of the house now, our once lives have changed. It is with all these considerations and the reminder that life is short but I sense that it is the right time to initiate this move out of my comfort zone. I look forward to pursuing many new challenges, some personal and some professional.  I also look forward to my continuing investment and involvement in Crown Castle in this capacity, ensuring leadership continuity as Executive Vice Chairman. I am proud of what we've accomplished. And through this succession plan, I'm highly confident this team will continue to reward shareholders, customers and employees for choosing Crown Castle.
Thank you to all of you on this call who has supported me and this management team over the years. I look forward to our continued association. 
With that, operator, we'd be happy to turn the call over for questions.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we will take our first question from David Barden with Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we will take our first question from David Barden with Bank of America.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know this is not the last quarter we're going to the chest of but thanks for all that in the contributions and Jay, congrats on the job. I'm looking forward to continue to work with both of you guys. The -- kind of focusing on the business as we kind of
componenttext: I know this is not the last quarter we're going to the chest of but thanks for all that in the contributions and Jay, congrats on the job. I'm looking forward to continue to work with both of you guys. The -- kind of focusing on the business as we kind of look ahead, I guess I've got a couple of questions. One, just on the obvious, with respect to kind of all the noise coming out of Sprint, with respect to their network architecture. We don't have to talk about Sprint necessarily the correct that that is looking to explore new more ways to build the network and it seems that they're looking to reevaluate their renewal schedule on the tower leases as we go forward. I was wondering if you can kind of talk about what if anything you see ahead for that strategy? And then second, Jay, a year ago, you were sitting here and I think the outlook was for new site leasing activity of maybe 5% and now we're sitting here looking at actually 6%, a better outlook for this year. Over the course of last year, that outlook actually went up by about a percentage point. So kind of what are the factors that you see maybe evolving in 2016 that could do to this year's guidance what happened in the last year's guidance in terms of walking it up the curve of touch over the course of the year?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Dave. This is Ben. First of all, without addressing Sprint what I'd like to talk about is the fact that 3 of the 4 carriers have reported thus far and I think all of them in various ways have confirmed the need for macro sites being an integral part
componenttext: Sure, Dave. This is Ben. First of all, without addressing Sprint what I'd like to talk about is the fact that 3 of the 4 carriers have reported thus far and I think all of them in various ways have confirmed the need for macro sites being an integral part of their network now and in the future, and that shouldn't be surprising any of us most of the business. Macro sites, i.e. towers, remains the most attractive and cost effective way to cover a given geography with the spectrum that they own. That said, there are certainly hybrid sites and architectures that we participate in, and many people do, that are going to augment the capacity of the networks going forward and that's the whole small cell underlay approach. And frankly, sites that look at like crosses between macro sites and small cells, dark fiber and that sort of see Cal architecture looks like over time. When you think about our business fundamentally, it's a capital-intensive business. Those with the lowest cost of capital tend to win. And when you introduce on top of that the notion of shared economics, i.e. the carriers only pay for the proportion of the assets that they need, it's an incredibly compelling model and it's one that I think it's going to continue to work as it has for the last 20 years for the investment in the future. So when carriers work on new deployments and new architectures with certain inappropriate due to save cost, we're going to be right there with them at every step of the way. And I can say that we're working with all 4 carriers in that regard to utilize our cost of capital and sharing model to be an integral part of their solution going forward. And so, I think it's been helpful for the last couple of weeks at 3 of the 4 carriers have confirmed that macro tower sites are an integral part of their model going forward. It's not surprising to us but I think this hybrid type network going forward is going to be very important and we're incredibly well positioned with assets and capability to take advantage of that. But when you hear us talk about cost of capital, it's not simply just to lower the cost on the balance sheet of our interest expense. It is very much to be the most competitive company out there that can deploy capital assets on behalf of these carriers and be very efficient for them. And that is something we're spending a lot of time on as an executive team and very comfortable with what you've seen in front of us.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the second question, last year, the 2015, we increased guidance over the course of the year, about half of that was driven from an increase in leasing activity and about half of that was driven from lower nonrenewals that what we have expected go into
componenttext: On the second question, last year, the 2015, we increased guidance over the course of the year, about half of that was driven from an increase in leasing activity and about half of that was driven from lower nonrenewals that what we have expected go into the year. So if you look at our guidance for 2016, we held that elevated level of leasing activities throughout the full year, full calendar year 2016 such that leasing activity we think this year will match that 2015. As for potential upside there, I'd point to the fact that typically in the business, we have about 6 to 8 months of visibility from the time we have an application from a carrier to the time it's actually revenue-producing. So we have a really good idea as to where our new tenant leasing is going to be for at least the first half of the year and maybe a bit into the third quarter. To the extent that there was an additional leasing activity over the course of the year, that's more likely to impact our run rates going into 2017 that it is to be that meaningful to results in 2016.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We go next to Richard Prentiss with Raymond James.
componenttext: We go next to Richard Prentiss with Raymond James.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: For first, congrats to Jay and Ben, it's been a great ride, launch our space for us and looking back at my notes, Crown is up 4 x since 17 years ago. So congrats to both of you guys. First question I've got is if a carrier does decide not to renew their l
componenttext: For first, congrats to Jay and Ben, it's been a great ride, launch our space for us and looking back at my notes, Crown is up 4 x since 17 years ago. So congrats to both of you guys. First question I've got is if a carrier does decide not to renew their lease, what triggers there? And do they have to remove the equipment? And how much does that cost?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Depends on the contract, Rick. Typically, our contracts require them to remove the equipment and restore the site. What we and we've got that many times the nonrenewals that just talk about we've experienced with the Nextel turn commode have often done th
componenttext: Depends on the contract, Rick. Typically, our contracts require them to remove the equipment and restore the site. What we and we've got that many times the nonrenewals that just talk about we've experienced with the Nextel turn commode have often done though is essentially negotiate a final payment if you will, what's commonly referred to the industry as pay and walk fee and that can be anywhere from sort of $30,000 to $50,000 per site depending on what's up there in the negotiations. But that's generally what occurs. But more often than not, we'll negotiate the final -- a final payments. That's typically the market condition.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Makes sense. Also this quarter was a top up in the SG&A line. Can you talk a little bit about what is occurring there? And should we think of that maybe as a revenue driver longer term?
componenttext: Makes sense. Also this quarter was a top up in the SG&A line. Can you talk a little bit about what is occurring there? And should we think of that maybe as a revenue driver longer term?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the SG&A a pop up, a bit of that would be related to having Sunesys for all 3 months of the quarter, Rick. And then the other part of it would be as the business outperformed our bonus level for across the employee base for the full year 2016 [ph] wo
componenttext: Yes, the SG&A a pop up, a bit of that would be related to having Sunesys for all 3 months of the quarter, Rick. And then the other part of it would be as the business outperformed our bonus level for across the employee base for the full year 2016 [ph] would have been above kind of our targeted level as we raised outlook throughout the course of the year and delivered and even exceeded it in the fourth quarter. I think if you look at kind or year 2016, we think the run rate is basically unchanged from full year 2015. As we talked about on previous calls, we think that there's virtually no cost increase at the GAAP line on the tower side or on the SG&A side for calendar year 2016, and that would be based on the current level of activity that we've seen at seen in small cells, et cetera. We obviously have some operating cost in small cells as we have deployed brand-new systems. But the most part of the tower side, we think cost are flat. And on the SG&A side, we think those costs are flat in '15 to '16.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That make sense. And Sunesys, you talked in the past about some extension maybe that could be done off of those existing fiber that Sunesys brought in. Was curious what you have seen in that extension mode?
componenttext: That make sense. And Sunesys, you talked in the past about some extension maybe that could be done off of those existing fiber that Sunesys brought in. Was curious what you have seen in that extension mode?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. The rationale behind the 10,000 miles of fiber we acquired metro fiber and great markets with Sunesys was that it would give us a great head start on small cell deployments and that's exactly what it is. But it's a head start. It's not a perfect foo
componenttext: Sure. The rationale behind the 10,000 miles of fiber we acquired metro fiber and great markets with Sunesys was that it would give us a great head start on small cell deployments and that's exactly what it is. But it's a head start. It's not a perfect footprint. And so as you referenced, we're constantly working to improve that network just as we do with existing Crown fiber where we get the new engagement and maybe there's, as I've described before, there's always overlap. So when you think of a tower co-location, which is a 100% co-location on existing site, a co-location or an additional on a Sunesys piece of fiber or a Crown fiber is always a hybrid. So there's always a percentage of overlap and a percentage of new typically, but and examples maybe otherwise like Manhattan where there was pretty full overlap. So that's working well. It drives our increasing sort of accretive yields on the assets. As I mentioned in my remarks, represents about 8% on the embedded capital like to date. And so as we're building additional -- either additional laterals or a combination co-locations, it's essentially driving up that yield over time. Now we're going to have better metrics for you in the coming quarters because of this is got a lot of moving parts to and we're going to come up with that for everyone to help with their modeling later in the year. What we focus on as a management team is ultimately yield on the investment capital. That cuts through all the metrics, whether it's tenants per node or nodes per mile or revenue per mile. And so we're going to help everybody with that later in the year so that we can all be clear. But that's how we've given you these sort of run rate yields. It's validating for ourselves as well, but we're continuing to see accretive investments in that space.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Brett Feldman.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Brett Feldman.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Progress do guys really exciting use. As we think about where you are deploying capital, you sort of listed a couple of potentially areas of investments. I might have missed it but I don't think you included towers on the list. I'm curious whether you fee
componenttext: Progress do guys really exciting use. As we think about where you are deploying capital, you sort of listed a couple of potentially areas of investments. I might have missed it but I don't think you included towers on the list. I'm curious whether you feel like the portfolio of towers that you have today is essentially the portfolio you will be operating in general for the foreseeable future. And then just as an extension, you talked about the importance of small cells and how you've invested in that. And as you see her carriers kind of evolve, how are you thinking about deploying network? Do you feel like the outdoor business that you have in the top 25 markets today is really what you need? Or do you see opportunities to create partnerships or make investments in other areas to further accelerate your positioning in that market?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brett. First of all, I didn't mean the towers at all. We bought 17,000 sites in the last, I guess, 3 years that are looking for more tenants. So those towers were acquired from AT&T mobile most recently, are very attractive co-location candidates an
componenttext: Sure, Brett. First of all, I didn't mean the towers at all. We bought 17,000 sites in the last, I guess, 3 years that are looking for more tenants. So those towers were acquired from AT&T mobile most recently, are very attractive co-location candidates and probably, not probably, absolutely represent the biggest value creation opportunity we have in the company and that is to co-locate on an existing power and we're quite happy with that going forward. The fact is that the carriers have essentially sold the vast majority of their sites. There's some small portfolios out there and it has been somewhat aggregated by the 3 large tower companies. So I don't see any large on the horizon another. It's certainly not a requirement for us to create significant value, as we just mentioned. The organic growth is what drives value around here. But I would also highlights, go back to 2001 and 2000 and 1999, when essentially the carriers sold out all their sites initially and then went to a whole another wave of that some 15 [ph] years later. So we do think there'll be a need for more tower sites over time as cell sites continue to shrink and requirements continue to increase. There's nothing significant other today and we're certainly advancing our leadership position on this newer architecture around small cells as we talked about. On the outdoor business for small cells, while we are about 90% focused in the top 25 markets, we're constantly looking at opportunities outside the 25 markets. And so your question, I think is how big could this be and the answer, we don't really know but it looks like it can be sort of a whole another tower business. It's hard. It's expensive. It takes a long time to build these systems. But at the same time, we are focused on what we think are franchise locations in something of a land grab that reminds us a lot of the early days of the tower business. And so, we're focusing our efforts in these top 25 markets, but I don't think it's going to be limited to that. In fact, I know it's not because we're looking at opportunities occasionally outside those markets. And it looks like it's got a long long runway.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's primarily outdoor opportunities? And it seems like there are a lot of different type of small cells solutions. There's indoor solutions and rooftops. And I'm just wondering whether those errors are picking your interest as well?
componenttext: And that's primarily outdoor opportunities? And it seems like there are a lot of different type of small cells solutions. There's indoor solutions and rooftops. And I'm just wondering whether those errors are picking your interest as well?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have an indoor business and we do quite well with it. Where we choose to play, we've done a lot of sports arenas, things like that. I think over time, you're going to see multitenant office buildings, but there are alternative solutions available
componenttext: Well, we have an indoor business and we do quite well with it. Where we choose to play, we've done a lot of sports arenas, things like that. I think over time, you're going to see multitenant office buildings, but there are alternative solutions available to landlords and tenants when you get into a multitenant facility but don't necessarily lend themselves to a mutual host owner like ourselves. A tenant in an office building can set up their own system or an office building can own their own system. There's a lot of different variations. And then there's a limitation in the marketplace still as to what the carriers will ultimately elect to pay for in terms of the rent. As we've said forever, and you all know this, there's more need in the market for a densification in network than there are hours in the day or capital that carries can invest. So there's a rational privatization going on. I think you're certainly seeing this extent to health care facilities now. And so we're certainly looking at the indoor business out there when we find it effective, but I don't think it's as large as the outdoor business.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Will go next to Michael Rollins with Citi.
componenttext: Will go next to Michael Rollins with Citi.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two if I could. Your first observation that you added more nodes on to a relatively flat amount of fiber miles, is that a trend that should continue? And how does that affect your return on capital opportunity from that business over time? And then second
componenttext: Two if I could. Your first observation that you added more nodes on to a relatively flat amount of fiber miles, is that a trend that should continue? And how does that affect your return on capital opportunity from that business over time? And then secondly, I'm curious what you're seeing on the propagation side for small cells and how would you compare the radius of a small cell in your experience versus the macro? And are there changes in technology that's going to affect that relationship over time?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the first question, Mike, you're pointing out a good observation there. You're right. Miles of fiber were relatively flat and we added nodes against those fiber miles. It's exactly co-location. I mean that's the business that we're in and why we'r
componenttext: Yes, on the first question, Mike, you're pointing out a good observation there. You're right. Miles of fiber were relatively flat and we added nodes against those fiber miles. It's exactly co-location. I mean that's the business that we're in and why we're interested in the tower business and why we like the small cell business. We have an asset investment against additional recurring revenue and that drives the long-term view of that invested capital and that's the model we're seeing play out, as Ben and I referenced in our comments. We've seen really attractive lease up activity on the fiber that we own today and that's driving additional nodes against number of miles of fiber. We're going to continue to see that as well as continuing to make investments as we build new systems and that's the driver of our activity at the moment. On the second question, the propagation characteristics of a small cell, there's no simple answer to that question or [indiscernible] answer to that question. It's designed based on what the carriers desire. And so you can go into a given area and find small cell every 100, 200 yards where they're trying to really increase the density of their network. At other places, you'll see space a little further than that. So there's no easy answer to say that propagation of the small cell has to do with what spectrum they deploy, what small cell, how much power they use, so it can vary. I would say in a typical urban environment, you're going to cover about a block to 2 blocks of area when deploy -- when the carriers deploy small cells. And so we will see what it was about every other block would be a relatively normal deployment into urban areas. But if you look at across the entire portfolio on an outdoor basis, we're typically -- when we're building a new system for someone, we'll be somewhere between 2 and 2.5 nodes per mile of fiber on the initial deployment so that gives you some idea of what we see. And obviously, there can be some pretty wide swings depending on whether or not we're doing the central business district or doing something outside of the density populated areas [indiscernible].

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Richard. It's Ben. It's very competitive and are the leader in the space and we have more capability for what we turnkey deployments, which is all-in building systems, locating the tenants on fiber that we build. But at the same time, there are other
componenttext: Hey, Richard. It's Ben. It's very competitive and are the leader in the space and we have more capability for what we turnkey deployments, which is all-in building systems, locating the tenants on fiber that we build. But at the same time, there are other very capable competitors out there and we see competition in the marketplace. It goes back to my original comments about cost of capital markers in this business. And so, that's something we focus on. I'm not going to get really get in to specifics around the market. A lot of the systems are conducted through an RFP process initially. But at the same time, what matters most to carriers obviously is the ability of the award winner to execute. And so, we have seen opportunities come back to us on occasion, where the awardee may have had some challenges in the market. What matters most carriers if they have a need for small cells is execution, meeting your milestones, getting on the air so that they can accomplish the capacity enhancements that they're trying to do on with their network. I think that's probably what I'll say on that, it's a highly competitive market these days.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Great. Then a quick follow-up, in terms of your guidance, should we think of the small cell business as rapping through the year? Or is this going to be more backend loaded as the builds kind of pileup so to speak?

componenttext: On both the towers and small cell side, the year is a bit back end loaded. It's about 40% of the activity in the first half of the year and about 60% in the second half of the year.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the first question, the percent around churn. We hesitate to comment specifically on what carriers are doing, and so I think I'll pass on that. It comes from several sources, John, not 1 single source. And we updated, as you have probably seen in
componenttext: Yes, on the first question, the percent around churn. We hesitate to comment specifically on what carriers are doing, and so I think I'll pass on that. It comes from several sources, John, not 1 single source. And we updated, as you have probably seen in the supplement, our expectation for churns in the next several years and that's an aggregate. I wouldn't say we're seeing anything at this point that I would point out that is changing our overall view of those nonrenewals. I think we've been pretty specific in the past about the amount of consolidation churn and nonrenewals and what is driving that and our underlying assumptions are basically intact. The second question on the tower side, we're seeing carriers do all kinds of things on the macro side. There's densification activity. There's amendments. There's adding new technologies. There's deploying additional spectrum that we have seen. And the mix of those amendments and new cell -- and brand-new cell sites in '16 is pretty similar to what we saw in 2015. So we're not seeing any trends here that I would point to as changes from what we saw in '15.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, just real quick, to add to that, we -- as we pursue the small cell business and we talked about it on this call and remainder about the opportunity, again, the first thing a carrier does is add densification is macro tower sites. And everywhere we'r
componenttext: John, just real quick, to add to that, we -- as we pursue the small cell business and we talked about it on this call and remainder about the opportunity, again, the first thing a carrier does is add densification is macro tower sites. And everywhere we're building small cells, there are macro tower coverages already there. So if were to expand on a street corner where we have a deployment, you would already have a macro site covering, keyword covering that geography and so we're building small cell networks essentially an underlay approach to add capacity to these network. But certainly, the macro tower side is what happens first and that's continuing to be what we see on the tower side.

componenttext: And then, I guess what in on the small cell, is there a different mix of demand or you've seen in terms of what carriers are coming on to infrastructure and then I guess related to that, and what Michael asked, as well as on the nodes that you expect to add this year, how much would be kind of along existing fiber activated with your infrastructure. The second is for tenancy,  if you will, along the same route, versus new laterals that haven't been activated in your infrastructure?

componenttext: I'll just say on the first question, when you go into any given year, there's an expectation we have around ranges for each of the carrier and I wouldn't point to anything in calendar year '16 that looks that much different from what we saw in 2015. We're seeing that both of the macro side as well small cells from all 4 of the operators. We saw that throughout '15 and we knew we would expect the same thing in 2016. On the midst of leasing small cells, it's about a 75% mix of where we're deploying brand-new system in places that we did not previously have small cell systems and about 25% of the leasing activity would be coming from all co-location on existing systems.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to echo the comments here, Ben, wish you the best of luck as you would a suspect will be an exciting transition for you and your family. In terms of questions, I've got 2, if I may. On the first, you mentioned some of the upcoming spectrum that see
componenttext:
I want to echo the comments here, Ben, wish you the best of luck as you would a suspect will be an exciting transition for you and your family. In terms of questions, I've got 2, if I may. On the first, you mentioned some of the upcoming spectrum that seems to be coming to market I mean obviously, there have been select carriers who talked about the opportunity set in terms of providing additional with the deployment of follow spectrum. But there've also been discussions about how networks are dense enough and have additional capacity and I'm just trying to sort of triangulate in terms of the opportunity set for you folks, I mean, do see those types of carriers looking to densify their networks? I mean, how should we think about the
[Audio Gap]

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All of the above. So as the carriers come in to launch a spectrum, to get maximum efficiency out of that very expensive spectrum, they're adding more equipment to the sites, to the existing sites. That just makes sense. The cost of that incremental amendm
componenttext: All of the above. So as the carriers come in to launch a spectrum, to get maximum efficiency out of that very expensive spectrum, they're adding more equipment to the sites, to the existing sites. That just makes sense. The cost of that incremental amendment on a tower is nothing compared to getting the maximum value out of that spectrum in that particular geography. And that's what's driving a lot of our amendment activity across all of the carriers and has for years. I don't see that changing. But in addition to that, you're not going to cover the capacity requirements simply by adding spectrum to existing sites. It's just mathematically impossible. You can't get the capacity requirements that are required. And so what happens is in addition to adding that spectrum on the existing sites, we're then seeing small cells added in an approach which gives the multiples of that spectrum capacity because they're better using the spectrum in that geography and unloading, effectively unloading the capacity challenge on the macro side. So you're going to see both. It's exactly what's driving our business today. The carriers are obviously being very rational about how do they prioritize their spend and they're looking at spectrum auction and having to pay for the spectrum often, and then how do they maximize the capacity over time. And then various carriers, they're in various stages of that today whether that's sulci densification or macro site amendments. All of that drives our business and is something that we think is going to continue for a long long time.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And dovetailing on to small cells, it seems as though it the growth has been a bit higher than expected. But of course, it also seems like we're still at the very early stages of adoption particularly when we think about sort of the initial hosting busine
componenttext: And dovetailing on to small cells, it seems as though it the growth has been a bit higher than expected. But of course, it also seems like we're still at the very early stages of adoption particularly when we think about sort of the initial hosting business model. I mean, there has been some chatter in the marketplace with folks discussing opportunities to densify their networks going at it alone in terms of utilizing certain technologies or potentially possible rights of access or microwave backhaul or how you want to look at the combination of different opportunities. How do you sort of compare and contrast the opportunity set that you folks have utilizing assets such as Sunesys or some of these land grab that you had mentioned versus carriers looking to potentially densify networks by small cells on their own sort of strategy?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you're going to see all of the above and it's not new if you think about it. Wireless carriers essentially rebuilt the tower portfolio on their own balance sheet since we have an industry acquired in the early 2000s and then elected to monet
componenttext: Well, I think you're going to see all of the above and it's not new if you think about it. Wireless carriers essentially rebuilt the tower portfolio on their own balance sheet since we have an industry acquired in the early 2000s and then elected to monetize it over time in the last 3 years. I think carriers will from time to time experiment with lots of different methods to add capacity to the network. That's not new. It goes back to the earlier comment and there's a lot different technology variations. I think it's generally accepted that fiber connectivity for small cells and towers ultimately through dark fiber connectivity provides the most flexibility and the most capacity for a given location. And so I think you're going to see over time that fiber, whether you're talking about fiber to the cell or fiber to the small cell, is a necessary element long term to accomplish what they need. And it goes back to the earlier comments on this call around cost of capital and sharing model. Certainly, it's possible for carriers to work and build their own systems and certainly, free to do that and operate in the same constraints that we do around permitting and zoning and rights of lay and things like that. But they can avail themselves of a lower cost of capital, allow themselves to put their capital back to work in their primary business, and we pass along some of that shared economics to them in that construct, that's going to make a lot of sense and it has for the last 20 years and that's what we're pursuing.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Been in check on that single on your next moves been a wonder if you just talk a little bit about your new role, I guess, if you're going to be real focus in strategy. How do you see spending your time? And what are the areas that you think you're going to be able to dive deeper into with your new responsibilities? And then sort of following up on the last question, Verizon has talked about a lot of that 5G with trials coming up in the next month or 2. Microwave's going to be frequencies are going to be deployed there. Have you had much conversations with companies and with the equipment companies about the opportunities there? And what that might mean over the next say 5 or 10 years? And we saw a fixed wireless launch yesterday. So it does look like there's other technologies, which are to appear in the horizon here. If you could just talk to that, that would be great.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. First of all, the role of Simon -- we're filling up the list but in terms of getting more items on it. I think initially, I'm going to certainly continue to spend time on industry matters, whether that's through PCIA or I'm on the board of both orga
componenttext: Sure. First of all, the role of Simon -- we're filling up the list but in terms of getting more items on it. I think initially, I'm going to certainly continue to spend time on industry matters, whether that's through PCIA or I'm on the board of both organizations and we're making some good progress there in the interest of our company as well as the broader industry. And I expect to continue in that capacity. And then also, I would expect to continue to work with the executive team on matters of strategy, capital location, some of the discussions we've had on this call point but would anticipate that given the longevity and tenure of this team, this executive team and Jay, particular, having worked together for 17 years and can finish each other's sentences, I don't think you have on to have a difference in opinion on strategy. So it's really going to be a bridge to the board and to industry that is that I think are increasingly important for us as we look to continue to have the ability to deploy wireless infrastructure in a very efficient way across the country. And just for those of this call, that is not getting any easier is that something that I'm pretty focused on.

componenttextpreview: On your second question, I think you can roll back the clock and see that if the carriers have migrated technologies, that those have almost always been aimed at improving the consumer experience, which generally codes for faster access to data networks a
componenttext: On your second question, I think you can roll back the clock and see that if the carriers have migrated technologies, that those have almost always been aimed at improving the consumer experience, which generally codes for faster access to data networks and those have always resulted in additional need for network densification. And I think regardless of if you had a loss of few opportunities there that are on the horizon. And we're seeing the carriers behave and think about the network whether we're talking to them about macro sites or small cells in a very similar way that it's going to result in additional network density being required, and we think that's great for our opportunity as we deploy capital and see additional yield on the capital that have already deployed.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The both of you, congrats with your new opportunities. First, I wanted to kind of just level set expectations around Sunesys. So can you just remind us how fast Sunesys grew in 2015? And then, what the implied growth rate is off of the $105 million [ph],
componenttext: The both of you, congrats with your new opportunities. First, I wanted to kind of just level set expectations around Sunesys. So can you just remind us how fast Sunesys grew in 2015? And then, what the implied growth rate is off of the $105 million [ph], which you guided for for 2016? I appreciate that Sunesys contributed $42 million to you in 2015, but I'm just trying to get the year-over-year comparisons. And then, just talking more about small cell, you mentioned your focus on 25 markets and obviously, looking beyond that. In those are 25 markets, how many of those are you where you're comfortable with the amount of fiber that you had? And really what I'm getting at is what's the likelihood of you going and doing another Sunesys like acquisition in 2016? How important is that if you think of strategy and areas you're focusing on for '16? And if that acquisition you were to do would come with a larger percentage of enterprise or wholesale of really, mass small cell, like business, in terms of how they're using the fiber, is that the business you're increasing at getting more comfortable getting into as we go forward so that you're no longer just a small cell fiber provided but really something much more broader than that?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, thanks for the questions, Colby. On the third question, when we did the Sunesys acquisition, I know initially when we announced it, we weren't sure exactly what the timing of the closing was going to be. The revenue growth year-over-year is a couple
componenttext: Sure, thanks for the questions, Colby. On the third question, when we did the Sunesys acquisition, I know initially when we announced it, we weren't sure exactly what the timing of the closing was going to be. The revenue growth year-over-year is a couple of million dollars to the guidance that we gave you was what we were expecting in 2016. And really, your 2 questions are fairly closely tied together. When we look at fiber in these markets and the opportunities that we're seeing more broadly than just Sunesys and whether that's expanding our portfolio on the top 25 markets, or has Ben referenced earlier, if we're looking outside of the top 25 markets, our aim is to own fiber that is supportive of the wireless carrier. That's our core business and that's what we're focused on. And so, when we look at opportunities for fiber, that's what we have in mind. What can we do with that fiber ultimately to drive yields on the capital invested and we think that yield is going to be primarily driven through investment by the wireless carriers and that's [indiscernible] with us or in some cases, fiber to the cell. There may be some acquisitions in the future albeit frankly, if we talked about when we did the Sunesys acquisition, we think that as it is really unique. It was dark fiber in major Metro markets in the U.S. And while we have found a few tuck-in acquisitions, like the one we did 2 years ago in the Baltimore-Washington area, those are relatively rare. So we're not thinking about this as getting in to per se the fiber business or expanding into the fiber business. Over time, we may find opportunities to add additional yield through recurring revenue sources across the fiber that we own, because of the location of the fiber, it's in urban areas where there's lots of density of population and so we may find opportunities to add additional revenue and drive return. But our focus both on the investment is always where we are focusing our sales efforts is around supporting our wireless carrier customers. That's what we really want do and what we want to be. And so that's where you are going to see us invest capital and focus over time both in the near term and what we believe currently has the the long-term strategy of the firm.
