headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Melanie, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today as we review our first quarter 2016 results. With me on the call this morning are Ben Moreland, Crown Castle's Chief Executive Officer; Jay Brown, Crown Castle's Chief Financia
componenttext:
Thank you, Melanie, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today as we review our first quarter 2016 results. With me on the call this morning are Ben Moreland, Crown Castle's Chief Executive Officer; Jay Brown, Crown Castle's Chief Financial Officer; and Dan Schneider, Crown Castle's Senior Vice President. To aid this discussion, we have posted supplemental materials in the Investors section of our website at crowncastle.com, which we will refer to throughout the call this morning. 
This conference call will contain forward-looking statements, which are subject to certain risks, uncertainties and assumptions, and actual results may vary materially from those expected. Information about potential factors which could affect our results is available in the press release and the risk factors section for the company's SEC filings. Our statements are made as of today, April 22, 2016, and we assume no obligation to update any forward-looking statements. 
In addition to today's call includes discussion of certain non-GAAP financial measures. Tables reconciling these non-GAAP financial measures are available in the supplemental information package in the Investors section of the company's website at crowncastle.com. With that, I'll turn the call over to Jay.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Son, and good morning, everyone. As highlighted on Slide 3, our first quarter results in exceeded the midpoint of our first quarter outlook and allowed us to raise our full year 2016 outlook. Our increased midpoint for full year 2016 outlook for A
componenttext:
Thanks, Son, and good morning, everyone. As highlighted on Slide 3, our first quarter results in exceeded the midpoint of our first quarter outlook and allowed us to raise our full year 2016 outlook. Our increased midpoint for full year 2016 outlook for AFFO per share of $4.70 represents an increase of over 9% compared to 2015. During the quarter, we also strengthened our balance sheet by accessing the bond market with our inaugural investment-grade issuance. This was another successful step in our effort to lower our cost of debt and equity capital. Operationally, we continue to invest in both small cells and towers, which we believe will drive future growth. These continued investments, together with our portfolio of approximately 40,000 towers and 16,500 [ph] miles of fiber supporting small cell deployments, position us as leading U.S. wireless infrastructure provider with unique capabilities and aspects to provide network solution throughout the country and across a variety of different network architectures. 
Shifting to the first quarter results on Slide 4. Site rental revenue grew 9%. The organic site rental revenue growth of $55 million represents growth of 8% year-over-year comprised of approximately 7% growth from new leasing activity and 3% from cash escalations, net of approximately 2% from tenant nonrenewals. 
Moving to Slide 5. Our first quarter results for site rental gross margin, adjusted EBITDA, AFFO and AFFO per share exceeded the midpoint of our previously provided first quarter 2016 outlook. Site rental gross margin benefited from approximately $1 million of one-time items that were not expected in the previously provided outlook comprised of a benefit to site rental revenue of approximately $4 million and offset by an increase to site rental cost of operations of $3 million. Additionally, AFFO for the first quarter 2016 benefited from $10 million and lower-than-expected sustaining capital expenditures, which is due to timing at full year 2016 outlook for sustaining capital expenditures remains unchanged. Excluding the benefit of these nonrecurring timing items, we still would've exceeded the midpoint of our previously provided first quarter 2016 outlook for each of these metrics. 
Turning to the investment activities during the first quarter. We invested $193 million in capital expenditures, of which, $10 million was sustaining capital expenditures and $183 million was discretionary investment. Consistent with our proactive approach to producing stable and growing cash flow over time, we invested $21 million in land purchases to further strengthen our control of the ground interest underneath our towers. Today, nearly 80% of our tower site rental gross margin is generated from towers on land we own or control from more than 20 years. Additionally, the average term remaining on our ground leases is over 30 years. The balance of our discretionary investments were in revenue-generating capital expenditures. A significant portion of this investment was in our Small Cell business, which today consists of 16,500 miles of fiber supporting approximately $385 million in annualized site rental revenue or approximately 12% of our consolidated site rental revenues. We are as excited as we have ever been by the opportunities in small cell. 
Our small cell conversations with the carriers have increasingly become more positive with the passage of time, and we are seeing the business model of small cell play out very similarly to that of towers. To that end, we thought it would be helpful to walk through 2 case studies that illustrate the co-location economics of small cells as the fiber infrastructure is shared among multiple carriers over time. 
On Slide 6, we lay out one of our systems in Denver. The initial system consisted of 14 miles of fiber connecting 18 tenant nodes on 18 poles for the first carrier. On the slide, the lines represent fiber that we own and the circles represent tenant nodes. We define the node as a tenant location that generates revenue and a pole as a physical structure on which we install the carrier's broadcast equipment. The picture shows a representative physical structure, under which, tenant nodes have been installed. 
Since the initial buildout, we have successfully added 2 additional wireless carriers to the system, which now consists of 17 miles of fiber connecting 65 tenant nodes supported on 26 poles located in the public right-of-way. In aggregate, the system currently generates a yield of approximately 20% based on the recurring cash flows and the capital we invested in the system. As you can see with the system, we have been able to leverage the initial investment by co-locating additional tenant nodes on the fiber to drive our returns. 
Turning to Slide 7. This is a system we have in Las Vegas. This system consists of 36 miles of fiber supporting 77 tenant nodes deployed on 77 poles for 2 carriers, generating a yield of approximately 13%. In addition, we are currently working with a third carrier to co-locate nodes on this fiber network and anticipate adding that third [ph] carrier to this system in the next 6 months. Unlike the Denver example, where the majority of the co-location of tenant nodes occurred on the same pole as the first carrier, in this example, the co-location occurred at different pole locations along the existing fiber. Because the majority of the investment relates to deploying fiber, our yield increased by co-locating additional nodes on our fiber regardless of whether the co-location occurs on the same pole  or on another pole along the fiber. This is why we often describe the fiber as a tower laid on its side, upon which we're aiming to co-locate tenant nodes. 
As we look at our entire small cell business, co-location of our fiber network has driven a meaningful improvement to the yield initially generated on the systems we acquired or constructed over the last several years. Given the returns we are seeing from small cell, we believe our continued investments are consistent with our strategy of allocating capital to drive long-term growth and dividends per share. 
Returning to investments and financing activities. Subsequent to the quarter, and as previously announced, we acquired TDC for approximately $461 million in cash. The TDC portfolio consisted of 336 towers located in the U.S. and Puerto Rico. Based on TDC's run rate contribution, the transaction is immediately accretive to AFFO per share. Consistent with our long-term capital allocation philosophy, we intend to pursue discretionary investment opportunities such as TDC and small cell that we believe will drive long-term growth and dividends per share. 
Continuing with financing activities, during the quarter, we paid a quarterly common stock dividend of 88.5 cents per share or $298 million in the aggregate. 
In January, we've closed on our current $4.5 billion unsecured credit facility and issued $1.5 billion in unsecured notes. These attractive debt transactions highlight the appeal of Crown Castle's high-quality cash flows and strong business model. 
Moving on to our full year 2016 outlook on Slide 8. We have increased our expectations at the midpoint for site rental revenues by $45 million, site rental gross margin by $31 million, adjusted EBITDA by $25 million and AFFO by $24 million. The increase in our full year outlook reflects the strong results from the first quarter, the inclusion of our TDC acquisition and the timing benefit related to tenant nonrenewal occurring later than we previously expected. It is important to note that our overall expectations for the number of tenant nonrenewals in the aggregate remain unchanged. 
On a per-share basis, AFFO is expected to be $4.70 at the midpoint compared to $4.30 in 2015, representing an increase of over 9% year-over-year. As you will hear from Ben, we believe that we are well-positioned well positioned to capitalize on the long-term positive industry fundamentals that we expect will position us to achieve our stated goal of delivering compound annual growth of 6% to 7% in AFFO and dividends per share. 
Lastly, I'm excited to welcome Dan to the Crown Castle team. Dan will step into the Chief Financial Officer role on June 1. He is a great addition to the team with his unique combination of financial and operational experience. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to Ben.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jay. Thanks for everyone joining us on the call this morning. As Jay mentioned, we are ahead of plan to deliver on our stated goal of generating AFFO per share and dividends per share compound annual growth of 6% to 7% organically, which remains o
componenttext:
Thanks, Jay. Thanks for everyone joining us on the call this morning. As Jay mentioned, we are ahead of plan to deliver on our stated goal of generating AFFO per share and dividends per share compound annual growth of 6% to 7% organically, which remains our long-term view. Our expectation is based on the intersection of 2 things: anticipated exponential growth and demand for wireless connectivity; and our unique portfolio of towers and small cells that can help carriers address their network needs. 
On this first point, according to Cisco, U.S. mobile data consumption grew 56% in 2015 compared to 2014. The year-over-year growth alone represents a staggering amount of data consumption. It is almost equivalent to all the mobile data that crossed the cellular networks in 2013. Importantly as we look out to the future, this growth is expected to continue. U.S. mobile data consumption is projected to increase sixfold between 2015 and 2020, a compound annual growth rate of 47% or roughly doubling every 2 years. Given these projections, and consistent with carrier commentary, we expect the carriers to continue to invest on a consistent basis to maintain and improve network quality. 
According to our recent survey conducted by consulting firm Accenture, 60% of residents were dissatisfied -- respondents were dissatisfied with their wireless connectivity and experience, while 71% of respondents would be willing to pay more for better connectivity. Against this backdrop, network quality is a competitive necessity as carriers seek to retain existing customers, attract new customers and drive further subscriber economics. 
Equally as important, network quality is a prerequisite as carriers seek to develop new revenue stream and used cases such as over-the-top video, machine-to-machine connection, smart city management and fixed wireless broadband. As we move beyond connecting people to connecting things, the reliability of networks become even more critical. The latency capacity and coverage required for connected cars or for smart cities that manage traffic and energy grids using mobile sensors for connections need to work everywhere all the time is much different than managing a network against dropped calls. A higher threshold of reliability and the corresponding need for network densification suggest that we're in the midst of a sustained investment cycle by the carriers. 
Across towers and small cells, we have a unique combination of assets and expertise that positions Crown Castle to assist wireless carriers in densifying their networks regardless of geography or network topology. As the leading U.S. shared wireless infrastructure provider, Crown Castle is assisting wireless carriers in this endeavor by providing them with speed to market and cost-effective access to wireless infrastructure. Our portfolio of approximately 40,000 towers with 72% located in the top 100 markets remains the first option in improving network quality, given towers efficiency and cost-effectiveness. With our existing base of over 80,000 tenant installations, we believe there's a long runway of growth opportunities via amendments as tenants add more capacity to their existing installations. Further, with an average tenancy of 2.2 tenants per tower, which effectively puts us at 40% to 50% occupancy, given the addressable market of the big 4 wireless carriers plus a host of other tenants opportunities, there are significant opportunities for new co-location as carriers work to increase network capacity by adding additional cell sites. 
We are further expanding the size of this opportunity by our investment in small cells, which is the natural extension of the carrier's network densification efforts needed to address network capacity. When presented with the challenge of providing continuous consistent high capacity, wireless broadband service across urban and suburban geographies, carriers are increasingly turning to small cells as an essential tool to improve their networks, as illustrated in the Denver and Las Vegas examples that Jay discussed. 
With small cells, we're investing in a business model that shares the same shared economic model of towers and we're encouraged by what we are seeing. Longer term, we believe we are well positioned to capture a significant share of this larger market opportunity. By focusing our investment in the top metro markets, we believe our fiber footprint of over 16,000 miles is in the right locations with the capacity necessary to support significant small cell deployment longer term. We believe this critical combination of location and capacity facilitates system deployments with time-to-market and economic advantages. To support the growth in small cells over the last several years, we have also built an organization that can execute at scale. Our team's deep RF fiber and real estate management skills and capabilities allow us to offer our customers a turnkey solution, a service level and value proposition that we believe is the best in the industry. 
While small cells are providing the much-needed additional network capacity, towers continue to play an important role in providing the first layer of coverage and capacity in an increasingly mobile world. In addition to bolstering network capacity through additional spectrum and cell sites, whether through towers or small cells, future networks are expected to add capacity by improving network architecture through increasing interconnectedness. As the only wireless infrastructure provider that can offer tower small cells solutions at scale, we believe we are in excellent position to capitalize on the future evolution of wireless networks through the extension of our shared infrastructure model, a model that continues to efficiently serve carrier needs and provide a compelling total return proposition of dividends and growth for shareholders. 
Before wrapping up, I'd like to extend my welcome to Dan Schlenker who's joining the team as CFO at June 1, as Jay mentioned, as we move forward with our announced succession plan with Jay Brown moving to CEO and my move to Executive vice Chairman. I am confident that our executive management team will continue to execute our business plan performing for customers and shareholders under Jay's leadership. 
Finally, I want to thank all my colleagues at Crown Castle who have worked so hard to achieve what we have accomplished. These men and women are true professionals. As their primary spokesman on these calls over the last 8 years, it has been my privilege to report to you their latest accomplishments every 90 days. I am confident there are many more accomplishments to come. 
With that, operator, we'll be pleased to address some questions.

componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could just talk about the overall leasing environment. We did see Verizon's CapEx and wireless down 9.5%, although they did comment about keeping the full year sort of back-end loaded. Is that what you're seeing here from the carriers broa
componenttext: I wonder if you could just talk about the overall leasing environment. We did see Verizon's CapEx and wireless down 9.5%, although they did comment about keeping the full year sort of back-end loaded. Is that what you're seeing here from the carriers broadly? And related to that, on the tenant nonrenewals, do you have clarity now about the timing of those disconnects? Or is it still possible that there will be further pushing out of this?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the first question around the leasing environment, as we talked about over the last couple of calls, our view is that leasing activity in the full year '16 is going to be very similar to what we saw in 2015. And we continue to hold that view. The
componenttext: Sure. On the first question around the leasing environment, as we talked about over the last couple of calls, our view is that leasing activity in the full year '16 is going to be very similar to what we saw in 2015. And we continue to hold that view. The guide that we've provided was based upon how we outperformed in the first quarter along with our view that the tenant nonrenewals were going to occur later in the year, and that's really what changed in our outlook. So our view of activity is about the same. Similar to past years, the other thing I would note is that if you look at our total new leases that we would expect during the course of the year, and that would be a combination of new leases on towers as well as amendments to existing leases, that activity is about 40% in the first half of the year and about 60% in the second half of the year. So it's back-end loaded but in about the same way as we typically find in the business. On your second question about the nonrenewal, our view is that in total, from consolidation that we talked about over the last several years, in total, we think that amount is about the same as it was previously. So we've moved out portions of that. Some portion of that we moved to 2017 and the balance of it we moved to periods that are beyond 2017. So at the moment, our view would be the total nonrenewal stays about the same. We're just pushing it up right a little bit. There's more details in the supplement if people would like to see how we moved each of those in our view in each of the calendar years. But I would say, overall, we think it's about the same total amount of nonrenewal.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brett. I think at the site gross margin line, obviously, as you bring on the new systems, we're going to bring on new costs, and so those markets are somewhat representative. But on what you would think as overhead, primarily people and infrastructu
componenttext: Sure, Brett. I think at the site gross margin line, obviously, as you bring on the new systems, we're going to bring on new costs, and so those markets are somewhat representative. But on what you would think as overhead, primarily people and infrastructure, it looks to us like we're getting pretty close to a stabilized run rate at this current level of activity. Now I qualify that because to the extent the pipeline would grow materially over time, these are fantastic investments and we've seen productive growth and yield on that investment and it takes additional variable cost in the form of overhead and people. So I would tell you, for modeling purposes, we are pretty close as of the Q1 run rate and less volume changes dramatically.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that specifically, if you're trying to do the year-over-year comparison, the step in the costs are obviously mostly related to the Sunesys acquisition, which comes at a lower margin, and therefore, the costs flow through. If you're looking at the
componenttext: I think that specifically, if you're trying to do the year-over-year comparison, the step in the costs are obviously mostly related to the Sunesys acquisition, which comes at a lower margin, and therefore, the costs flow through. If you're looking at the incremental margin, the incremental margins are not going to look as high as what we typically see when we're constructing new small cell systems. SO I think that would be one thing I would raise. And then if you look at the total cost structure for the full year, as we talked about last quarter, the G&A in the fourth quarter -- third and fourth quarter of last year is about what we expect for the full year 2016. So by time we exit the year if we're looking at a full year basis, it starts to stabilize but you're still in the effects if you do Q1 '15 over Q1 '16 as the cost grew throughout calendar year [indiscernible].

componenttextpreview: So the other side of that gross margin question is it looks like your tower gross margins are calculated a little lower than what we would have thought given your peers. And what's driving that the difference? Or am I just completely missing something?
componenttext: So the other side of that gross margin question is it looks like your tower gross margins are calculated a little lower than what we would have thought given your peers. And what's driving that the difference? Or am I just completely missing something?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's 2 components, Phil, that's driving it. One is, as we've discussed, the churn is basically offsetting a big portion of the new leasing activity that we're seeing. And then as you look at the GAAP revenue numbers and the segment for towers,
componenttext: I think there's 2 components, Phil, that's driving it. One is, as we've discussed, the churn is basically offsetting a big portion of the new leasing activity that we're seeing. And then as you look at the GAAP revenue numbers and the segment for towers, you don't see in those GAAP numbers the benefit of the escalation, the contracted escalation that we have in the business as those are straight-lined over the term of the lease. So when you go bound to the AFFO metric, we get the benefit at the AFFO line of those cash escalations. The other component I would point out is, as we talked about last quarter around some of the fees that we received when tenant nonrenewals occur, we refer to those commonly as pay and walk fees that we received from carriers. Last year, there was about $30 million to $40 million of those pay and walk fees in our services business. We don't expect anywhere close to that scale of activity in calendar year '16 as we saw in '15. And so as we've guided down in services from the renewables, those kind of fees to the tune of about $30 million to $40 million year-over-year. And so if you're just looking at the tower segment and you're looking at adjusted EBITDA or the segment operating profit, you're going to see mostly impacted from those none -- what we would refer as noncore services activity.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the other side, long term, where do you see small cell gross margin, operating margin reaching? How do we compare that to the tower margin?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the other side, long term, where do you see small cell gross margin, operating margin reaching? How do we compare that to the tower margin?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think if you looked at an individual system, what you would find is when it gets to 3 carriers, the direct margins from those systems against the direct operating costs, those margins are very likely to be higher than what we typically would find with t
componenttext: I think if you looked at an individual system, what you would find is when it gets to 3 carriers, the direct margins from those systems against the direct operating costs, those margins are very likely to be higher than what we typically would find with the tower that had 3 tenants on them. As a part of -- if you look at the whole business, there's 2 things that affect that, back to my prior comment about the Sunesys acquisition, obviously, the incremental growth in revenues is going to be offset by the cost that come with an acquisition. So if we have acquisitions, that will impact the totality of the margins in that segment. But the other aspect to it is that we are deploying a meaningful amount of capital to build additional fiber and additional small cell networks. And as we put those systems on air, they're going to tend to mute the growth that we would have. There's a bit of a -- we often refer to it as like advantage analysis internally where we look at the system similar to those that we shared this morning in Denver and Las Vegas that we've had on air for a period of time, as we add those tenants the direct margins on those systems will look -- we believe will look at least if not better than what towers would. But as we look at the totality of segment, it's going to depend on how much investment opportunity we have there as to whether or not the full benefit of that co-location flows through to your margins, whether it's offset by the value of investing in future systems that come along at a lower margin level.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And most importantly, obviously, is yield on the capital. So we start off typically at a higher initial yield in the tower and then grow it over time at typically a rate that exceed the equivalent tenancy on the tower, so that was some of Jay's comments a
componenttext: And most importantly, obviously, is yield on the capital. So we start off typically at a higher initial yield in the tower and then grow it over time at typically a rate that exceed the equivalent tenancy on the tower, so that was some of Jay's comments around those 2 case studies.

And I noticed you're now breaking out the CapEx for the small cells, specifically, which would allow us to kind of track that return evolution on a go-forward basis. If you could kind of bring us up to speed on the total capital investment at this point in time kind of as a starting point for 1Q '16, that would be kind of a helpful beginning so we can kind of see how that's evolving. And then second, these slides on the system developments are super helpful, I think, in part because they give us some granular node and pole detail, which I think would be super helpful to have to have for the totality of the Small Cell business, which I notice is part of the disclosures anymore. So could you give us an update on some of the metrics that go along with these new revenue numbers, would be great.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think the simplest way, Dave, to look at where we are in the business is to annualize sort of the run rate margin in the segment so 61 times 4, call it, $240 [ph] million or against $3 billion of capital spend over time. And it's easier to remembe
componenttext: Sure. I think the simplest way, Dave, to look at where we are in the business is to annualize sort of the run rate margin in the segment so 61 times 4, call it, $240 [ph] million or against $3 billion of capital spend over time. And it's easier to remember the 3 because if you can remember, the 2 distinct to that was one was $1 billion for NextG at about a 4% yield and the Sunesys acquisition last year of $1 billion at about 6% yield. So you can see, obviously, the incremental modulation on that last $1 billion is very significant in the sort of double digits to drag the whole thing up. And that's illustrated -- that's a macro view and it's illustrated in Jay's 2 case studies we walked through. So it's a great question and it's one we look at. It's probably the #1 thing we watched, which is, are we dragging that overall yield up with that incremental contribution both from new systems and then the co-location that occurs. And as Jay said, it's a long raise because as you bring on new systems to single tenants, it's a land grab, not unlike the tower business has been. So you're bringing on somewhat lower yields and then I think grows over time. In terms of metrics, one of the things -- and we've given you a lot more detail realize around segment reporting, that will probably increase over time. One of the things that Jay was talking about was tenant nodes, and that's why we illustrated these 2 systems, where you can have tenant nodes locate by themselves on the common fiber. So if they have collocated themselves where you have 2 tenants on 1 pole or you can have 2 tenants on 2 poles. And so the node metric is somewhat confusing or lost and it's why I think it makes sense to go back to sort of financials. And then over time, there's various things that we made a slide to discuss would be revenue per fiber my, for example, obviously a key driver. The fiber is the vast majority where the capital goes, and so we're working to find some simple metrics [indiscernible] one like we have in the tower business it's not quite as simple, but hopefully, it's getting better.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Jonathan Atkin with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll go next to Jonathan Atkin with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I was interested in learning a little bit about just the Sunesys contribution to incremental growth if there's anything color you can provide there given your legacy lines of business. And then secondly, was interested in what the competitive envi
componenttext: Yes. So I was interested in learning a little bit about just the Sunesys contribution to incremental growth if there's anything color you can provide there given your legacy lines of business. And then secondly, was interested in what the competitive environment is around small cells from other fiber-rich providers. And then I've got a quick follow-up after that.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, on your first question, as we talked about the Sunesys acquisition, our view of that was that was fiber plant that provided an opportunity for us over time to reduce the capital costs required for us to deploy small cells. So we put it into the
componenttext: Yes, John, on your first question, as we talked about the Sunesys acquisition, our view of that was that was fiber plant that provided an opportunity for us over time to reduce the capital costs required for us to deploy small cells. So we put it into the business and we're not focusing on it as a separate business from our overall Small Cell business. So the contribution there -- frankly, we're much more focused on driving the return as Ben talked about on the full $3 billion and using that fiber to deploy additional small cells against it. With regards to the competitive environment that we're in, obviously, there are a number of folks who look at this business and see it as attractive and concurrent -- can obviously see the public comments with the wireless operators they're making about the importance of small cells and how they're necessary to improve their networks along the lines of what Ben's comments were and the necessity of small cells in order to accomplish the density of networks that are required to meet the consumer's expectation for devices. And so we do find competition -- sometimes that competition comes from more nationally based of fiber operators. And then in other times they were in certain markets, there may be a provider of fiber that's specific to a single market alone and so we'll run into them as we're going to the process of a request for proposal from the carriers, where a local provider may be in that process. So at the end of the day, we believe that our opportunity here is based upon our access to a cost of capital and a return on that capital that we think is very attractive given what we've seen over the long period of time that we've been in the tower business. We also believe that we're the best at it. So we have built, in terms of scale, I think unmatched scale and operating capabilities when compared to anyone. And certainly, as we talk to the wireless operators, we make that case. The last thing that I would say in terms of what we run into is the vast majority of the fiber and small cells are purpose-built. They need to be in specific locations, long routes where we can install on poles as we showed in some of the fixtures and illustrating some of the cases. And this fiber is very different than -- we believe it's very different than what we've seen historically deployed. And so as we go out and purpose-build this fiber, it really -- as we're in the process of working with the carriers, that's where the operational expertise and scale is helpful to us to win those next projects.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, on Denver and Las Vegas or any other kind of equivalent examples that you have, where there's 2 or more tenants, I'm just interested about what is it about those deployments that made small cell the right solution for the tenant? And did the ten
componenttext: And then, on Denver and Las Vegas or any other kind of equivalent examples that you have, where there's 2 or more tenants, I'm just interested about what is it about those deployments that made small cell the right solution for the tenant? And did the tenant come off any nearby micro sites as they located onto your infrastructure?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. In both cases, there are -- as you can see from the map, there are locations there that would obviously make sense for towers to be located and there are, and those carriers have macro coverage in both Las Vegas and Denver in those areas, that small c
componenttext: No. In both cases, there are -- as you can see from the map, there are locations there that would obviously make sense for towers to be located and there are, and those carriers have macro coverage in both Las Vegas and Denver in those areas, that small cells are large and an opportunity for the carriers to offload some of the data traffic off of the macro site onto a small cell, which improves and enhances the value of the macro site to cover a larger geography. And we have not seen, as we've deployed -- as we talked about nearly $385 million of run rate revenue, we have not seen carriers come off of macro sites. In fact, we believe and from the comments the carriers have made, in our own experience, it actually enhances the value of their macro site. So this is a product that enhances their network. It's not a substitute. And the last point I would make about that is from a cost standpoint, if there's a macro site that solves the problem or the challenge or improves the network, the macro site is always preferable as a solution because it's much more cost effective to the carriers. So small cells are a solution when macro sites really can't solve the need. And then it becomes a necessary component of the network at that point.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Ric Prentiss with Raymond James.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Ric Prentiss with Raymond James.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we've been pushing a long time for small cells segment, so much appreciated. In the no good deed goes unpunished, I'm going to ask more questions about it. I appreciate what your comments were about node as kind of confusing, but can you help us under
componenttext: And we've been pushing a long time for small cells segment, so much appreciated. In the no good deed goes unpunished, I'm going to ask more questions about it. I appreciate what your comments were about node as kind of confusing, but can you help us understand what the pipeline is or what the revenue growth might be on the small cell side? I think, previously, maybe like $55 million was going to be anticipation of what small cell incremental might be in '16.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct, Rick. We still believe that the contribution to revenue growth is about $55 million. So I made the earlier comments about Tower. I actually said the same thing about small cells. Our view of revenue growth is unchanged in terms of what we
componenttext: That's correct, Rick. We still believe that the contribution to revenue growth is about $55 million. So I made the earlier comments about Tower. I actually said the same thing about small cells. Our view of revenue growth is unchanged in terms of what we expect in calendar year '16 from the contribution of small cells of about $55 million in the 2 [indiscernible] .

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there any broad tenant per system number? I know you got a mixture of vintages, but also trying to match other co-location trends, how best to think of that.
componenttext: Is there any broad tenant per system number? I know you got a mixture of vintages, but also trying to match other co-location trends, how best to think of that.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think maybe over time as we continue to develop and enhance the operational information systems that we have internally, and obviously as we broaden the Sunesys acquisition and the growth we've seen in the business, we're working on that. We may come to
componenttext: I think maybe over time as we continue to develop and enhance the operational information systems that we have internally, and obviously as we broaden the Sunesys acquisition and the growth we've seen in the business, we're working on that. We may come to a place where we have an operating metric that we think is helpful. Frankly, as we manage the business, what's a little different between small cells and towers is that I wouldn't describe the rent as much as a standard rent, as what you typically see in towers. The systems are priced and we provide them to the carriers based on a return. And so as we look at the business, we tend to go back to the financials and look at what's the net capital we're investing in the system against the recurring cash flows in those systems and then how do we price appropriately both the first tenant and then future tenants on the system. So we've talked about things like you remember back in the early days of the tower business where we have things like the DDEs, which is a broadband equivalent for towers and that was a revenue metric. We just want to make sure that as a focus kind of the next leg of disclosure the business have gotten larger that we described it in a way that is helpful. And so we may over time get to a place where we feel like some of those metrics are more helpful. But at the moment, we think probably the best way to focus the attention is around the segment reporting that we provided. And then some of these case studies may be helpful to start to understand operationally how they're deployed, how the carriers think about them and how we're investing capital in the fiber, against which we're trying to co-locate as many nodes as possible.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if so, we should not be thinking really as a rent per node, which is the old way more of a yield return base, how much we spend on the network, is that how much you're suggesting?
componenttext: And if so, we should not be thinking really as a rent per node, which is the old way more of a yield return base, how much we spend on the network, is that how much you're suggesting?

componenttext: Yes. Our contract in small cells are very similar to that of towers where we have an initial term of 10 to 15 years and annual escalations on those revenue stream. Similar to towers, they would be straight lines over the term of the lease and the cash escalations would grow on an annual basis.

componenttextpreview: All right last question. So much detail [indiscernible] back to Brett's question on the margin side. It did seem like G&A as a percent of small cell revenues went up sequentially from 4Q to 1Q, and you would've thought -- we would have thought Sunesys wou
componenttext: All right last question. So much detail [indiscernible] back to Brett's question on the margin side. It did seem like G&A as a percent of small cell revenues went up sequentially from 4Q to 1Q, and you would've thought -- we would have thought Sunesys would have been fully baked into 4Q. So we're just trying to figure out is that really more midteens we're talking about or just trying to understand that quarter-to-quarter difference also.

componenttextpreview: A little bit hit Q4 to Q1.
componenttext: A little bit hit Q4 to Q1.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think as we're building the run rate and folding in Sunesys, some of the -- as we look at the Sunesys acquisition, some of the expertise, as we found in, frankly, the other acquisition that we've done over time, we found opportunities for folks tha
componenttext: Yes, I think as we're building the run rate and folding in Sunesys, some of the -- as we look at the Sunesys acquisition, some of the expertise, as we found in, frankly, the other acquisition that we've done over time, we found opportunities for folks that we thought could continue to grow and enhance our business for the long term. So we probably ended up retaining a few more folks than we would have thought initially going into the process. And so as people come out of what would've effectively been the pulldown and rundown of the prior business, that we're now folding them into the run rate on the ongoing small cell segment.

componenttext: Right, and no breakout on Sunesys anymore, is that what we should expect?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Matthew Heinz with Stifel.
componenttext: We'll go next to Matthew Heinz with Stifel.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up on the small cell competitive landscape question, I'm curious how you see the exclusivity of these systems in the given Metro area? I guess are most of the anchor builds you're doing now kind of the first of their kind in the Metro? And how
componenttext: As a follow-up on the small cell competitive landscape question, I'm curious how you see the exclusivity of these systems in the given Metro area? I guess are most of the anchor builds you're doing now kind of the first of their kind in the Metro? And how much sense would it make for a competitor to come in and put up competing systems in the general vicinity of the ones you've already built?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Matthew. There's a lot of inherent exclusivity in what we're building, and it goes really to the purpose-built nature of the fiber and the very significant capacity and strand count that's required on these systems today. So while it's possible for
componenttext: Sure, Matthew. There's a lot of inherent exclusivity in what we're building, and it goes really to the purpose-built nature of the fiber and the very significant capacity and strand count that's required on these systems today. So while it's possible for someone to come in, we don't have exclusivity on -- somebody can come overbuild technically. Economically, it doesn't make any sense, and I would go back to the question of the addressable market and the competitive landscape. It is an enormous world out there obviously when you start looking at the world block by block. And I look at your in Houston, I look at Houston today, where there's 2 large systems getting built, one by ourselves and another by a competitor, and we don't overlap at all. And so that's the way these are working kind of all across the country where it makes sense. I think it's unrealistic on our part that I think carriers can give us 100% of their market share in a particular area. As much as we love that to happen, that's just not realistic. And so we have competitors. They're gaining in terms of their own capability and the economics around the transactions make it such that very much like towers, it just doesn't make any sense once you have the capacity in the market and you have 1 or 2 carriers already on that system to come in and essentially duplicate that infrastructure. It's not already there, I guess, is the point, and we're having largely build it or occasionally buy it like we did with Sunesys where some of you will recall when we bought Sunesys it was only 27% utilized on average in terms of strand count. So we have a lot of capacity in those metropolitan markets where Sunesys fiber was it's obviously the type of speed market advantage and efficiency around the cost, a lot cheaper to buy it with the run rate than build from scratch.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then the second question. I'm wondering how we should think about the services revenue and OpEx you're allocating to small cells. And seeing as it's coming in at a much lower margin than the tower services revenue, is that sales o
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then the second question. I'm wondering how we should think about the services revenue and OpEx you're allocating to small cells. And seeing as it's coming in at a much lower margin than the tower services revenue, is that sales or that revenue primarily coming from carrier reimbursements on the anchor builds?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's largely related to equipment that gets installed. In some occasions, the carriers will actually have purchased the equipment -- their equipment to the system and then there's a slight market to that, which is how the margin is generated. As you
componenttext: Yes, it's largely related to equipment that gets installed. In some occasions, the carriers will actually have purchased the equipment -- their equipment to the system and then there's a slight market to that, which is how the margin is generated. As you can see from the numbers, it's a relatively small contribution to services gross margin, a couple of million dollars. We don't expect that to grow. It's very different than what we would expect on the tower side, obviously. So frankly, from a margin standpoint, and I'll think that's interesting, I would tell you that our expectation would be we'll probably produce somewhere between $2 million and $10 million a year of margin, but unlikely to be more than that from services margin in the Small Cell segment.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, yes. I mean I guess I wasn't trying to get a sense where the reimbursement revenue is flowing into. And it sounds like the site rental piece is kind of -- more of a pure number on where rental dollars are.
componenttext: Okay, yes. I mean I guess I wasn't trying to get a sense where the reimbursement revenue is flowing into. And it sounds like the site rental piece is kind of -- more of a pure number on where rental dollars are.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to a Amir Rozwadowski with Barclays.
componenttext: We'll go next to a Amir Rozwadowski with Barclays.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to dovetail some of the other questions on small cells. Just wondering how do you feel about your current asset footprint. I mean as you mentioned, this is seemingly like a tower line on its side. Is there potential for you to build out that capacity
componenttext: Just to dovetail some of the other questions on small cells. Just wondering how do you feel about your current asset footprint. I mean as you mentioned, this is seemingly like a tower line on its side. Is there potential for you to build out that capacity by additional inorganic means in order to accelerate sort of build new footprint? And then I got one follow-up after that.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Amir, this is Ben. We take a big step with initially NextG, which is a little bit early maybe and has worked out pretty well and then Sunesys last year with the footprint we acquired to a point. We have also done 2 or 3 smaller just sort of single market
componenttext: Amir, this is Ben. We take a big step with initially NextG, which is a little bit early maybe and has worked out pretty well and then Sunesys last year with the footprint we acquired to a point. We have also done 2 or 3 smaller just sort of single market deals that made sense based on specific engagements that we have where we can buy versus build. And then we're constantly looking at those opportunities, but there's nothing out there on the horizon that's significant today. But I would tell you that it has to pass the filter of we're supporting wireless infrastructure, first and foremost. We're supporting the wireless sort of broadband capacity buildout that's happening on the small subnetworks. And so that takes us to these top 25 metros typically, which is an enormous geography to cover when you start to think about it that way, again by a block by block level. So there's not just many than in the universe of sort of addressable targets. We may do a few more, but I wouldn't say there's anything on the horizon right now that looks like Sunesys.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then switching a bit away from the small cell discussion. It seems there's been a debate at least in the investor community and maybe one of the carrier partners on how to think about the AWS 3 spectrum deployment over them into longer term, particula
componenttext: And then switching a bit away from the small cell discussion. It seems there's been a debate at least in the investor community and maybe one of the carrier partners on how to think about the AWS 3 spectrum deployment over them into longer term, particularly as to whether or not pre-existing either MLAs or preexisting equipment can facilitate the deployment of that spectrum. I would love to hear your thoughts around that. Can this be an opportunity for further amendment revenues as that spectrum gets deployed? And what are you guys thinking in terms of timing?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Amir, I think what I would say to that end, we try to be pretty careful about this over the last several quarters with the carriers. We don't want to get in front of them in terms of what their network architecture is, and that's really a question they sh
componenttext: Amir, I think what I would say to that end, we try to be pretty careful about this over the last several quarters with the carriers. We don't want to get in front of them in terms of what their network architecture is, and that's really a question they should speak to, how they're thinking about equipment and installations on towers. I would tell you as we look at the activity in total on towers, we think that, that activity, which is going to come from a myriad of sources including the one you referenced, we think that's about the same level of new leasing activity this year as what we had last year. That's a bit elevated from the levels that we saw in 2014. And as we talk about our long-term target, that Ben and I both mentioned, that 6% to 7% growth in AFFO and dividend per share on an annual basis, what we've embedded in that is a leasing environment for towers that looks fairly similar to the environment we're currently in today. And our experience over a long period of time is that as the carriers either acquire additional spectrum or upgrade their technologies to the newest and latest technology, it's the sources of that revenue growth tend to move among the carriers among the technologies and among the spectrum band, but we see a relatively consistent amount of revenue growth year-to-year. In fact, as you go back over a multi-year period, you can find that the vast majority of the leasing activity in any given year is within a band of about 10% to 20% up or down. And so it gives us a lot of confidence in the business as we think about longer term, our 6% to 7% metric in AFFO growth that it would appear to us our assumption of that current level of leasing growth is a fairly well-placed assumption as we look at it through a different a number of different cycles over a long period of time. So we certainly spend some time watching and having conversations with the carrier about what they're doing specifically with certain technologies. But we'll let them to speak for that and we'll focus on what we think the impact kind of revenues are as they take those various actions over time.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to finish the thought, for most of you, you've heard me say this many times, that up or down 20% on tower leasing in any given year is about a 1% change in AFFO per share outcome and one of the many reasons we like this business.
componenttext: And just to finish the thought, for most of you, you've heard me say this many times, that up or down 20% on tower leasing in any given year is about a 1% change in AFFO per share outcome and one of the many reasons we like this business.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Michael Rollins with Citi.
componenttext: We'll go next to Michael Rollins with Citi.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up and a couple of quick questions. With regards to small cells, is there a way to think about the backlog of revenue relative to capital that's already been recognized in the financial statements like you either haven't turned the service o
componenttext: Just a follow-up and a couple of quick questions. With regards to small cells, is there a way to think about the backlog of revenue relative to capital that's already been recognized in the financial statements like you either haven't turned the service on yet or it takes time for the customer to kind of grow into the full revenue spend that it's committed to?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It generally takes us about 18 to 24 months to build a brand-new system. So we have a pipeline that we're currently working on today. It would be in the soft [indiscernible] stage for systems that we won't turn on likely until 2017 and 2018. For new
componenttext: Sure. It generally takes us about 18 to 24 months to build a brand-new system. So we have a pipeline that we're currently working on today. It would be in the soft [indiscernible] stage for systems that we won't turn on likely until 2017 and 2018. For new tenants, when they're -- as they're co-locating on existing systems, that process can take anywhere between 9 and 18 months depending on the dynamics in the market. And so we have a pipeline of those activities as well. What we're seeing in terms of the revenue growth in small cells this year of $55 million, those would've been projects that we started a number of years ago that are now into the run rate. So I would say, in small cells, we have a little bit more visibility about what the revenue growth is going to look like given the construction time frame, whether that's co-location or new system. So we do have a view for that. And back to my prior point, that's baked into our view of growth of 6% to 7% AFFO per share. So we're assuming that we continue to see the current level of activity over an extended period of time. To the extent that we have opportunity beyond that, then we have to revisit that growth rate. That working assumption is that we both invest in the activity that's in and around the same levels we're currently seeing.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you have an update on how the acquisitions, the 2 big tower portfolios that you acquired over the last few years, how they're doing in terms of growth versus the rest of the portfolio? And then just a final thing I was curious about is just back to the
componenttext: Do you have an update on how the acquisitions, the 2 big tower portfolios that you acquired over the last few years, how they're doing in terms of growth versus the rest of the portfolio? And then just a final thing I was curious about is just back to the churn questions from earlier in the call. Is there a reason the carriers are giving you for the delay in turn relative to what you anticipate. It seems like that churn keeps getting pushed out, which you get more money in the interim for that. But is there a reason for it? And part of that may be a possibility that you wanted to keep some of those locations that you would anticipate that you want to churn?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mike. On the AT&T and T-Mobile acquisitions that we did, those towers in terms of their new revenue growth are performing in line with the rest of our towers. So we haven't seen any meaningful difference in leasing, which was our underwriting assump
componenttext: Sure, Mike. On the AT&T and T-Mobile acquisitions that we did, those towers in terms of their new revenue growth are performing in line with the rest of our towers. So we haven't seen any meaningful difference in leasing, which was our underwriting assumption going into those acquisitions. In both cases, we assume that we would add about 1 tenant per tower per year over the first 10 years of ownership. And as we look at our consolidated results, that's about what we're seeing in terms of new leasing activity across the whole portfolio, and we're seeing it pretty consistently across many. On your second question about churn, we've obviously had discussions with the carriers but again, I'd like to be careful -- regarding some of those conversations. They've been pretty public about their desire to ramp those legacy networks down. We think the locations are obviously great. And at some point, we're picked specifically for the network. So there may be the opportunity over time for some of the sites to get reused. But based on what the carriers have been publicly indicated to us, we think the best long-term assumption is to say that those sites will eventually not be renewed, and so we take that into our outlook.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Colby Synesael with Cowen.
componenttext: We'll go next to Colby Synesael with Cowen.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions if I may on growth. First now you're breaking out on small cells versus the macros, I'm wondering if you can tell us I guess the proximity of organic growth for each of those 2 business that get us to that 8% that you did in the first quarte
componenttext: Two questions if I may on growth. First now you're breaking out on small cells versus the macros, I'm wondering if you can tell us I guess the proximity of organic growth for each of those 2 business that get us to that 8% that you did in the first quarter. And also, when I look at that 8% as part of the aided [ph] 6.8% growth in new leasing activity when I look at your guidance for the year, you're assuming it's just 6%. So obviously, some point between the next 3 quarters you're assuming that goes below that number. And this is your response to I think it was Simon's question, you mentioned you're still expecting 60% of activity in the back half of the year versus 40% in the first half. So I'm trying to understand why you'll be going below 6% [ph] over the next 3 quarters to get your guidance versus the 6.8% you just did in the first quarter.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the first question. I think it's probably a level of granularity that, at this point, we haven't disclosed around organic growth. You can obviously see from the 2 businesses that the growth on small cells is much higher on a percentage basis than
componenttext: Sure. On the first question. I think it's probably a level of granularity that, at this point, we haven't disclosed around organic growth. You can obviously see from the 2 businesses that the growth on small cells is much higher on a percentage basis than that of towers, which, in part, comes from the fact that we're coming off a much lower base. And so if we add tenant nodes across the systems, that's going to result in higher percentage growth. With regards to the 6.8% moving down towards 6% over the course of the year, we look at the business and find it to be helpful to look at it much more on a year-over-year basis rather than taking into kind of quarter-to-quarter as there can be things, whether it's the timing of the non-tenants non-renewals or the timing of leasing, that impact that. And you brought up exactly the right point when you referenced my earlier comments to Simon about 40% in the first half of the year and 60% in the back half of the year. What happened in past years as 60% of the leasing activity went on the towers late in the balance of 2015, those come into the run rate obviously, it's reported numbers, whether that's GAAP numbers or the organic metrics that we have. Those won't show up until basically the first quarter in fulsome this year. So that has some impact to those numbers. And as we go over the course of the year the licenses and I was specifically referring to the new leases that we build with carriers over the course of the year, those leases that we signed in the fourth quarter this year will have very little to no impact to site rental revenue in this calendar year. Those will just be in the run rate as we go into the next calendar year. So there is some balancing over time that leads to those differences. The other thing I would point out is just -- you just got the law of large numbers. So as you move through this over time from a percentage basis, we're going to lose somewhere in the neighborhood of about 40 basis points assuming a constant level of activity, 40 to 50 basis points, on the revenue growth number from an activity standpoint and that's why we spend so much time talking about $115 million of nominal growth. And on the tower side, that's really the best indication of what the activity doing either up or down from kind of that baseline number. So the percentage change is a combination of looking at quarters and trying to figure out what does it look like period-to-period and then also the law of large numbers.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And probably also, we should speak to the 6% to 7% longer-term view on AFFO is inclusive of the headwind from law of large numbers and why you come off a higher-year this year, 9% in the guidance. And then over time, when you look at the convert coming in
componenttext: And probably also, we should speak to the 6% to 7% longer-term view on AFFO is inclusive of the headwind from law of large numbers and why you come off a higher-year this year, 9% in the guidance. And then over time, when you look at the convert coming in next year, for example, and things, that's sort of a fully baked number and includes the inherent accretion from making smart capital allocation decisions that drive that over time.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Spencer Kurn with New Street Research.
componenttext: We'll go next to Spencer Kurn with New Street Research.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So are you seeing any competition from cable companies in your small cell markets? And can you sort of elaborate what exactly is so different about the purpose-based fiber that you're deploying for small cells versus the existing fiber in a lot of those m
componenttext: So are you seeing any competition from cable companies in your small cell markets? And can you sort of elaborate what exactly is so different about the purpose-based fiber that you're deploying for small cells versus the existing fiber in a lot of those markets? I know cable has been leveraging their fiber for Wi-Fi hotspots, which seems pretty similar to what carriers would need for a small cell. But yes, I'd love some -- I'd love to hear your thoughts on what's different and why you have agreed to it.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, the cable companies in various markets would be in the list of competitors. From time to time, we run across them. And in particular, your question center around the uniqueness of the fiber, it really goes to the capacity and the fact that all the c
componenttext: Sure, the cable companies in various markets would be in the list of competitors. From time to time, we run across them. And in particular, your question center around the uniqueness of the fiber, it really goes to the capacity and the fact that all the cable plant, whether they dedicate it to either sort of cable or enterprise, is experiencing dramatic growth in bandwidth requirements across the universe. And as we look at what these small sales require in terms of typically a distributing them into the system architecture takes a pair of [indiscernible] for every node. That's a very -- essentially like a dark fiber connection. That's a very significant burden to put on existing plant in many markets. And so certainly, there are some, like we found Sunesys capacity. Obviously, we moved on that. But as a general matter, it's not uniform and it's not interchangeable, and so you're really have to look at it sort of almost block by block, city by city where we have an engagement and where we can take advantage of existing fiber either through leasing something occasionally or acquiring it, we will. But that's in the vast minority except for the footprint we acquired with Sunesys. So that's probably not as clear as we can be. Appreciate that bandwidth requirements for all connectivity is going up, not just wireless.

componenttext: On the acquisition pipeline, from time to time, we may find an opportunity that makes sense to acquire [indiscernible] some towers in. TDC was a bit of a unique circumstance for us. That was a firm that we partnered with back in 2008, 2009  time frame to go out and build towers and acquire some towers and then we have an option to call those assets in at an appropriate -- what we thought found was an appropriate financial returns for some future date. So we exercised a call option that we have in the transaction. We see towers from time to time trade, but they're relatively small acquisition. And frankly, most of the capital as we've had opportunities to deploy it outside of the TDC acquisition, which I would describe as a bit unique, we focus most of our efforts in capital investment on small cells and have not seen attractive multiples in the tower space recently.

componenttext: And want to talk to you a little bit about -- I apologize if I missed a little bit, but the margins for small cells, I understand the heavy investments in the near term. But how should we think about expansion of margins of gross and operating margins going forward? And then one thing I note is also straight line revenues, the adjustment keeps coming down. Is that basically what we should anticipate continuing here as we layer in the small cell business as well?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the first question, the margins on small cells are impacted by 2 things. One was the Sunesys acquisitions that we did. So that makes the incremental margins in growth and revenue a little different than what we would typically see. It was just sy
componenttext: Sure. On the first question, the margins on small cells are impacted by 2 things. One was the Sunesys acquisitions that we did. So that makes the incremental margins in growth and revenue a little different than what we would typically see. It was just systems without the acquisition that we put into it. So that's part of the impact. The other thing is exactly what you said, which is we have systems that have been on air and are benefiting from co-location as well as we're putting meaningful amounts of capital investment in for systems that start with just 1 tenant. And so the combination of those 2 things, along with the co-location is what yields -- what [indiscernible] out the ultimate yield from that margin. Again, we're looking at 2 things. One is the underlying business, is co-location happening and how does that develop over time. And then the second thing is as we allocate capital, new capital on new systems, does that makes sense against the broader environment. We think on both fronts, we're growth our comfort in our business and encouragement and excitement about what could be in the small cell business as it develops a very similar to what we've seen over a longer period of time in towers. To your second question about straight line revenues, just taking the simple example of a 10-year lease in the first 5 years of that 10-year lease, the reported GAAP revenues would be above the cash received. And in the second 5 years of the 10-year contract, the cash received would be above the GAAP revenues. So as you note on that slide, we refer to that as the revenue eclipse that is occurring and we're nearly there. We believe without meaningful amount of extensions would likely be the case over the next several years is that we'll have cash receipts that are in excess of reporting GAAP revenues. And that's why we spend so much time focusing on AFFO per share because it removes that vagaries and focuses on the cash receipts from those lease contracts.
