componenttext: And we'll go to Colby Synesael with Cowen and Company.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions, if I may. The first one, I'm just curious if you're finding that having both a macro portfolio as well as small cells is helping one another? So having small cells has helped your macro business or having macro in a given area has helped yo
componenttext: Two questions, if I may. The first one, I'm just curious if you're finding that having both a macro portfolio as well as small cells is helping one another? So having small cells has helped your macro business or having macro in a given area has helped you win small cell deals that were otherwise, I guess, being competitively bid. And then my second question has to do with the cost of small cells. So at CTIA, one of the takeaways I had was that the carriers are pushing that if we're going to build out hundreds of thousands if not millions of these over a period of time, versus today the typical carrier has, I don't know, 40,000 or 60,000 or 70,000 macro cell sites out there, the cost has to come down significantly. And there's talk about is $500 a node or $200 a node the right price. And one of the ways I've thought about it is that you could actually, as a fiber provider, go and share that cost not just across various wireless carriers, but across other industry vertical that might be interested in fiber, such as health care or cloud companies or financial services or education, et cetera. How big of a focus is that for you? And do you see yourself splitting the cost or sharing the cost of fiber in small cells with those other verticals? And does that become an increasing area of focus for you as we go forward?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You bet, Colby. On your first question related to does having small cells help the macro tower business, I would start by just affirming, as we've done multiple times on the call, the tower business is a phenomenal business. And whether you're in the smal
componenttext: You bet, Colby. On your first question related to does having small cells help the macro tower business, I would start by just affirming, as we've done multiple times on the call, the tower business is a phenomenal business. And whether you're in the small cell business or not, we think there's tremendous value that has been created in the tower business, obviously. But we also believe there's a tremendous amount of value that's going to be created in the tower business. And we don't view being in the small cell business as a requirement to be successful -- continued success around the tower business and the growth opportunity there. So I don't think you have to be in the small cell business. The opportunity that we see in small cells, we're there because we believe that will increase and drive dividend growth over a long period of time. So we believe it's a smart allocation of capital that continues to further the growth model but don't view it as a necessity to be in. There's certainly incrementally -- at senior levels of the carriers, it enables a broader conversation about how they're thinking about network deployment. We think that's helpful and informative to us as we think about the long term as we can have a broader conversation. But depending on the returns, there may be a day when we choose not to invest as heavily in small cells. So it's really a return-driven analysis for us but would admit there is some incremental value around the conversation with the carriers. On the second point and your question around the costs need to come down. Again, just like in tower, small cells are shared infrastructure asset that the economics of which are far more attractive to the carriers as a result of us sharing among multiple parties than they would be if they were self-performed or built for only one carrier. So the costs, effectively, are coming down by us being a third-party provider and the initial carrier not bearing the full cost of the deployment and on the ongoing operating cost. We're going to share that across multiple operators. As we think about the potential growth drivers of revenue and cash flow over time, if we think about that as a shareable asset, our primary focus remains on the wireless carriers. And so using this fiber deployment for small cells, we think, is the vast majority of the economic driver for both growth and the opportunity that we see. We have -- as you know from our Sunesys acquisition and in certain geographies, we've used our fiber to provide things like K-12, which is providing broadband to schools. Those are long-term contracts that have provisions that are very similar to towers and that of small cells. And that obviously puts fiber in the areas where people are located and where there's a density of population. And so we've found over time those -- there are some real synergies of revenues around using that fiber for both schools and then, ultimately, small cells or small cells and then secondarily to schools. So there may be, over time, ways for us to continue to sweat the assets. That's not our primary driver at this point, but we do look at some specific cases where we see opportunities for us to expand the revenue and the cash flow.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matthew Heinz with Stifel is next.
componenttext: Matthew Heinz with Stifel is next.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could kind of give us a little more detail on the approximate split of new construction and co-location activity that's contemplated in your small cell guidance for roughly the $70 million of new leasing, I guess, just to get a sense of t
componenttext: I was hoping you could kind of give us a little more detail on the approximate split of new construction and co-location activity that's contemplated in your small cell guidance for roughly the $70 million of new leasing, I guess, just to get a sense of the capital intensity of that growth.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. About 75%, roughly 3/4 of the growth is being driven by the deployment of new systems in areas where we don't have systems today. And that could be -- when I say new areas, that could be like the Chicago example where we're expanding beyond the cent
componenttext: Sure. About 75%, roughly 3/4 of the growth is being driven by the deployment of new systems in areas where we don't have systems today. And that could be -- when I say new areas, that could be like the Chicago example where we're expanding beyond the central business district but still in the Chicago market. And then about 1/4 roughly of the activity is coming from co-location on existing plant.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just to confirm, the new construction activity does go under new leasing. Is that correct? I guess...
componenttext: Okay. And then just to confirm, the new construction activity does go under new leasing. Is that correct? I guess...

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a little bit different from maybe how you would account for a new tower?
componenttext: It's a little bit different from maybe how you would account for a new tower?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct. On the tower side, that is separated over in the acquisitions and new tower build. As the Chicago example shows and the reason for doing that -- first of all, you're accurate in your description. We have both the new and the co-location in
componenttext: That's correct. On the tower side, that is separated over in the acquisitions and new tower build. As the Chicago example shows and the reason for doing that -- first of all, you're accurate in your description. We have both the new and the co-location in the leasing bucket on the left-hand side of the chart there. And then on the tower side, if we build a new tower, that goes over in tower builds and acquisition. So your assumption is accurate. We do that because we find it very difficult to allocate both capital and revenue or cash flows. As we'll build laterals on existing systems, at what point is the lateral a new system versus a part of the existing system? And so for ease-of-use, we've just combined those. And again, 3/4-plus of the activity at this point continues to be the deployment of new systems.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you mentioned that potential upside to your guidance was possible. And you think that if that were to occur it would most likely be on the co-location side?
componenttext: Okay. And then you mentioned that potential upside to your guidance was possible. And you think that if that were to occur it would most likely be on the co-location side?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Matthew, I would point to the opportunity for us to do it both on the deployment of additional systems as well as co-location. We think those 2 things will go hand in hand. We're building the early stages of this plant very similar to the early days o
componenttext: No. Matthew, I would point to the opportunity for us to do it both on the deployment of additional systems as well as co-location. We think those 2 things will go hand in hand. We're building the early stages of this plant very similar to the early days of towers, where towers were being deployed starting at the central areas of urban areas and then expanding out into the suburb. And that's happening in small cells. We think that will continue, from the markets that we've been in where the vast majority of the activity has been, in and around the top 10 markets in the U.S. We see that expanding outside of the top 10 markets. We also see it expanding beyond sort of the central business districts of those markets. So our expectation today would be that, over time, we'll continue to invest additional capital as the carriers deploy small cells to improve their network.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful. And then if I could just go over to the nonrenewals. It looks like the expected churn from acquired networks in '17 was down $15 million at the midpoint from your last report. I'm just wondering how I should square that up with
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. And then if I could just go over to the nonrenewals. It looks like the expected churn from acquired networks in '17 was down $15 million at the midpoint from your last report. I'm just wondering how I should square that up with your comments that churn -- nonrenewals have been pushed out from '16 into '17. And then if I sort of split out the acquired network churn from the normal churn, I get to about $30 million of "normal churn" or 90 basis points, which I think is probably below your historical experience. Just wondering what you're seeing there in the business that's kind of reducing the go-forward churn expectations on the normalized side.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Matthew, to your first point, squaring up the '16 to '17 move. Some churn was pushed out from '16 to '17, but other churn was pushed out from' 17 to beyond. So you can see the beyond column in our supplement will go up as well to make up for that.
componenttext: Yes. So Matthew, to your first point, squaring up the '16 to '17 move. Some churn was pushed out from '16 to '17, but other churn was pushed out from' 17 to beyond. So you can see the beyond column in our supplement will go up as well to make up for that. So what it looks like is there's lower churn than we expected in '16. And even though some of that pushed out into '17, some got pushed even further out. So that's how you square those 2 things, if that makes sense. And then in terms of the normal churn, I think you're right. You back out what we see as consolidation churn and it leaves around 90 basis points is your math. I would say a little -- around 1% is what we're seeing right now, yes. And it is a little less than what we've seen historically and talked about historically. But 1% is what we're seeing now.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Spencer Kurn with New Street Research.And hearing no response, we'll move on to Nick Del Deo with MoffettNathanson.
componenttext:
We'll go to Spencer Kurn with New Street Research.
And hearing no response, we'll move on to Nick Del Deo with MoffettNathanson.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I recognize it's early in the process, but can you speak to what you're seeing in terms of amendment revenue from AWS-3 upgrades? More specifically, are the amendment rates consistent with past amendment cycles? Or are customers trying to put up antennas,
componenttext: I recognize it's early in the process, but can you speak to what you're seeing in terms of amendment revenue from AWS-3 upgrades? More specifically, are the amendment rates consistent with past amendment cycles? Or are customers trying to put up antennas, they can run both AWS-1 and AWS-3, which might garner more modest incremental rents?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, on the amendment side, we're seeing pretty similar, both rates, on the equipment as well as size of equipment, et cetera, from an amendment cycle. So it looks pretty similar to what we've seen over many years. We would expect -- I mean, as you refer
componenttext: Nick, on the amendment side, we're seeing pretty similar, both rates, on the equipment as well as size of equipment, et cetera, from an amendment cycle. So it looks pretty similar to what we've seen over many years. We would expect -- I mean, as you referenced, given what's going on in the market, amendment activity as a component of total leasing activity may increase as a percentage of that in 2017 as the carriers focus on some of the activities that you referenced.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then maybe a longer-term question. If I look at your '17 outlook, if my math is right, you seemed to be guiding to something like an incremental cash EBITDA margin on site leasing revenue of about 80% next year. Or maybe about 75% if you
componenttext: Okay, great. And then maybe a longer-term question. If I look at your '17 outlook, if my math is right, you seemed to be guiding to something like an incremental cash EBITDA margin on site leasing revenue of about 80% next year. Or maybe about 75% if you strip out the amortization prepaid rent. Is that something we should be thinking of as sort of a normal incremental margin over next several years given the tower and small cell mix? Or do you think there's a potential to do better as the small cell platform scales?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now let's separate the 2 and talk about towers and small cells separately. On the tower side, when you look at the cost structure, both at the direct operating expense side and at the G&A side, we're holding costs, effectively, flat. We would expect in no
componenttext: Now let's separate the 2 and talk about towers and small cells separately. On the tower side, when you look at the cost structure, both at the direct operating expense side and at the G&A side, we're holding costs, effectively, flat. We would expect in normal course, just the cost of living adjustment to be about 3% increases year-over-year. And we're well inside of that on towers, basically holding everything roughly flat year-over-year. So that drives incremental margins that are extremely high, well over 80%. About 90% would be our expectation  as we think about 2017 on the tower side. On the small cell side, we've got a combination of 2 things going on. On the systems where we're co-locating, we're seeing very high incremental returns which expand the margins on the systems where we're seeing co-location. As we put new systems on air, those -- the margins on those new systems are in the neighborhood of about 60% for a new system. So those immature assets, if you want to think about them that way, those immature assets with slightly lower margins than the overall average basically hold the average down. And we don't see the full benefit of the incremental margins that we're seeing on small cells from a co-location standpoint. And how that progresses over time will largely be a function of how many opportunities do we have in front of us, how much do we invest on the deployment of additional systems, and then the margins will fall out from there. If you fast-forward all the way to the end of this, when the market becomes more saturated in terms of the deployment of those systems, what we see on individual systems is margins that expand at paces that are in line with what we've seen historically for towers. And so rolling forward to a very long view of small cells, I think you'll continue to see the margins expand and approaching levels that we've enjoyed in the tower business.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Nick, before we move off of that, just if you look at the $35 million increase in OpEx and G&A year-over-year, that's less than 3% of our total cost of structure. And that's an increasing activity. So I do think that what Jay was talking about is we'r
componenttext: And Nick, before we move off of that, just if you look at the $35 million increase in OpEx and G&A year-over-year, that's less than 3% of our total cost of structure. And that's an increasing activity. So I do think that what Jay was talking about is we're seeing some of that operating leverage now.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll now go to Michael Rollins with Citi Research.
componenttext: We'll now go to Michael Rollins with Citi Research.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can refer to your press release, where you do the floating bar charts, where you break down the leasing activity, the escalators, the renewals, et cetera. Why not move the impact of prepaid rent amortization from the organic convers
componenttext: I was wondering if you can refer to your press release, where you do the floating bar charts, where you break down the leasing activity, the escalators, the renewals, et cetera. Why not move the impact of prepaid rent amortization from the organic conversation over to the way that you look at straight line and acquisitions? And if you were to do that, can you help us think through what that says about what activity might have been in 2016 versus what activity looks like in 2017?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the [indiscernible] is because prepaid rent really is an economic decision that our customers and we are making together. And we're getting that rent either upfront or as part of the ongoing operation of the business. So it is really tied in some
componenttext: Yes. So the [indiscernible] is because prepaid rent really is an economic decision that our customers and we are making together. And we're getting that rent either upfront or as part of the ongoing operation of the business. So it is really tied in some -- on some levels to the new leasing activity. So it is part of the economics we enter into. And if we hadn't gotten the rent upfront, we'd be putting it in new leasing activity revenue. But if we don't put it there or take credit for it from the capital side, it gets lost in that. So we think of it as tied to leasing activity. The reason why it's growing less isn't necessarily reflective of the current activity in '16 or '17 because the current -- the activity in '16, we said, is about flat from '15 and is about flat to '17. That's why it is actually plateauing, and the growth and prepaid rent amortization is coming down. So what it's speaking to is, specifically on the tower side, is the growth is the same year-over-year, which is why you're not seeing incremental prepaid amortization. Whereas on the small cell side, you are because we're continuing to invest in that business, grow it and get more prepaid rent that we're collecting on that business.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And plus you could say and maybe just an additional point there, which maybe was the second part of your question. Given that we've referenced the amortization was related to the tower business, basically, towers on an apples-to-apples basis is about flat
componenttext: And plus you could say and maybe just an additional point there, which maybe was the second part of your question. Given that we've referenced the amortization was related to the tower business, basically, towers on an apples-to-apples basis is about flat of about $90 million, roughly, year-over-year. And then on the small cell side, it's up $15 million. So it's gone from about $55 million to about $70 million. So if you thought about it and you wanted to exclude kind of the prepaid conversation from that analysis, then the growth is up about 100 basis points if you were to take -- if you were saying take a portion of that graph and move it kind of over to the right-hand side. And that 100 basis points is being driven entirely from small cells.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then if you look at the $55 million to $70 million for small cells, how much of that is being driven by incremental co-location versus capital spending in deploying new systems?
componenttext: And then if you look at the $55 million to $70 million for small cells, how much of that is being driven by incremental co-location versus capital spending in deploying new systems?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say it's about that same split. So I'd put about 3/4 of that to new systems and about 1/4 of that roughly to co-location.
componenttext: I would say it's about that same split. So I'd put about 3/4 of that to new systems and about 1/4 of that roughly to co-location.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Batya Levi with UBS.
componenttext: We'll go to Batya Levi with UBS.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: A follow-up on the CapEx side. As you look to invest more on the small cells next year, can you provide maybe a dollar amount in terms of how much construction CapEx you expect to spend? And more strategically, as you're looking to invest more in small ce
componenttext: A follow-up on the CapEx side. As you look to invest more on the small cells next year, can you provide maybe a dollar amount in terms of how much construction CapEx you expect to spend? And more strategically, as you're looking to invest more in small cells, can you talk about your decision-making process in terms of building versus acquiring for more fiber assets and maybe leveraging some -- your REIT multiple into looking to acquire some assets that are not getting the REIT multiple?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take the first one and I'll probably defer to Jay on the second one, which is on the capital side, on the construction, it's similar year-over-year from '16 to '17 on the small cell side. So you should expect to see, generally, the same amount of s
componenttext: Let me take the first one and I'll probably defer to Jay on the second one, which is on the capital side, on the construction, it's similar year-over-year from '16 to '17 on the small cell side. So you should expect to see, generally, the same amount of spending.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Batya, on your second question, we will look at and will continue to look at opportunities to acquire fiber assets. But the driver of that, as I mentioned earlier around our strategy, is to lease that fiber to wireless operators primarily for the use of s
componenttext: Batya, on your second question, we will look at and will continue to look at opportunities to acquire fiber assets. But the driver of that, as I mentioned earlier around our strategy, is to lease that fiber to wireless operators primarily for the use of small cells. And so to the extent that we can identify fiber in a given market that we think makes sense on that basis, then we would be interested in the asset, but we don't spend a lot of time around here thinking about arbitrage within multiples and things. Businesses are valued where they're valued. And so our approach is to invest capital in ways that drive the dividend over the long term, and our strategy for doing that is focused on the wireless operators and deploying small cells.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next is Walter Piecyk with BTIG.
componenttext: Next is Walter Piecyk with BTIG.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on the co-location. Can you define what that means? Is that just putting another radio in the box that's already on the lamppost? Or does that also include connecting a lamppost that happens to be right above your fiber?
componenttext: Just a quick question on the co-location. Can you define what that means? Is that just putting another radio in the box that's already on the lamppost? Or does that also include connecting a lamppost that happens to be right above your fiber?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It would be both of those, Walter.
componenttext: It would be both of those, Walter.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then very interesting chart, Chicago. The 5 you said gets you to 10% returns. So just 2 questions on that. In 5 years, how many tenants per mile do you expect to get? You can obviously give a range and best-case scenario, worst case, whatever,
componenttext: Got it. And then very interesting chart, Chicago. The 5 you said gets you to 10% returns. So just 2 questions on that. In 5 years, how many tenants per mile do you expect to get? You can obviously give a range and best-case scenario, worst case, whatever, assuming that we get to like, as an industry, 1 million-plus small cells, that type of backdrop. And then if you can just give us some sense -- I know this is not easy. But assuming this 75%-25% mix that I think you've referenced now 3 times on the call, how the returns would increase as that 5 tenants per mile goes up. Is it like 200 basis points per tenant? Or any way you can scale that for us as far as the implied returns of adding additional tenants per mile.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think in Chicago, I'll punt on how many tenants per node per mile of fiber we're going to ultimately get to. These systems -- and just to take you back to kind of how we would think about underwriting Chicago and how we did think about underwriting
componenttext: Yes, I think in Chicago, I'll punt on how many tenants per node per mile of fiber we're going to ultimately get to. These systems -- and just to take you back to kind of how we would think about underwriting Chicago and how we did think about underwriting Chicago, we would look at return based on the cost of deployment of the fiber. So obviously, in a central business district, as you would expect, the cost of deploying that fiber would be significantly greater than as we move out to suburb, generally speaking in a metro market. And so the number of nodes required to get to an acceptable IRR or yield on that investment is going to differ based on the cost. What I would tell you generally, Walter, is that the pace of leasing on small cells has been about twice the pace of that of towers that we've seen historically. And the returns, to kind of your last question, the returns track that. So we're 3 years in on the Chicago system, roughly from 2013 to 2016 and then some of that under construction in this 2017, so call it 3 to 4 years of snapshot there. And the yield is in the double-digit area, around 10%. That took us over a decade in the tower -- on the tower side. And that kind of yield on invested capital is well in excess of our cost of capital and provides a terrific return. Now we certainly don't think we're done in Chicago. We're early days on this. And so we think the yields and returns continue to expand well beyond what we underwrote when we invested that capital.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So -- but I mean, as a rule of thumb, if 5 went to 10, presumably, your returns would be much higher than 20%, right? It has to scale up from there, I would think, right?
componenttext: So -- but I mean, as a rule of thumb, if 5 went to 10, presumably, your returns would be much higher than 20%, right? It has to scale up from there, I would think, right?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's exactly right.
componenttext: That's exactly right.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one last -- just a little pushback on the urban versus kind of suburban being more expensive. If that's the case, why wouldn't every operator just opt for someone that actually already had fiber in the market rather than go with someon
componenttext: Okay. And then just one last -- just a little pushback on the urban versus kind of suburban being more expensive. If that's the case, why wouldn't every operator just opt for someone that actually already had fiber in the market rather than go with someone that had to build new stuff?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The answer is that there's barely anything there. So most of the...
componenttext: The answer is that there's barely anything there. So most of the...

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the urban part of Chicago? I would think that there's fiber running up and down the streets.
componenttext: In the urban part of Chicago? I would think that there's fiber running up and down the streets.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This fiber is purpose-built in locations that there is not a capacity of existing fiber to be able to handle these small cell nodes. There are other places where we have utilized some leased fiber, where there was existing fiber in the ground. Obviou
componenttext: Yes. This fiber is purpose-built in locations that there is not a capacity of existing fiber to be able to handle these small cell nodes. There are other places where we have utilized some leased fiber, where there was existing fiber in the ground. Obviously, that's a more cost-effective opportunity. But the vast majority of what we're doing, there's not a fiber in the ground to provide this. And if there is fiber in the ground, there's not nearly enough capacity to be able to handle small cells.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would also say that we agree with you that when we have fiber in the ground, like now you can see in Chicago, we have a great advantage of getting more small cells on that as opposed to somebody coming in and building because of all the things Jay has t
componenttext: I would also say that we agree with you that when we have fiber in the ground, like now you can see in Chicago, we have a great advantage of getting more small cells on that as opposed to somebody coming in and building because of all the things Jay has talked about and you just mentioned is we have an advantage at this point, and we expect to see leasing on that fiber. And where we don't and have seen where other people have a tremendous amount of fiber that would be utilized for small cells, we understand the disadvantage we're at and will at times choose not to go into those markets. So I think part of what you're talking about is the competitive dynamic around these things, and we feel like we have a great position competitively both from our capability standpoint but also from our footprint standpoint to really accelerate growth in this business.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take the next question from Michael Bowen with Pacific Crest.
componenttext: And we'll take the next question from Michael Bowen with Pacific Crest.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question, I may have missed it, but have you divulged any number of tenants per small cell site? Or can you give us any thoughts on, if not, kind of where you might see that going in both the near and the distant future and kind of the technology around i
componenttext: Question, I may have missed it, but have you divulged any number of tenants per small cell site? Or can you give us any thoughts on, if not, kind of where you might see that going in both the near and the distant future and kind of the technology around it and how well that's working? And then with regard to the carriers, we've been hearing, obviously, a lot of chatter around pressure from the carriers trying to reduce revenue escalators. Are these current conversations happening? Are they not happening? Can you give us any idea on -- I understand you talked about value proposition, and I get all that, but trying to get an idea as to whether this is something that might be imminent.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Michael, appreciate the questions. We haven't disclosed the number of tenants on small cells. We have focused, as you heard from Dan's comments, on yield and return on the investments that we've made. So I think you're going to continue to hear us me
componenttext: Yes. Michael, appreciate the questions. We haven't disclosed the number of tenants on small cells. We have focused, as you heard from Dan's comments, on yield and return on the investments that we've made. So I think you're going to continue to hear us mention that. That way, you can look at the financial statements and see the expansion of that yield. We think that's the best way to judge it given how much the economics vary on a market-by-market basis. Number of nodes may not be really indicative of the return. So we're focused much more on the capital investment and then what the return of that capital investment is. On your second question around the carriers and conversations, as I mentioned a little earlier, we've seen no change in the pricing construct with our tenants. And given the value proposition that we provide for those carriers, with the cost to lease the assets of something in and around a little bit less than 3%, we think that model continues to hold well into the future.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our final question today comes from Michael Hodel with Morningstar.
componenttext: Our final question today comes from Michael Hodel with Morningstar.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had a question on the Chicago map, again going back to that. There are certain areas where I would have expected to see maybe a little bit more density actually. Think of a market like Oak Park, where you have an affluent suburb that's urban in nat
componenttext: I just had a question on the Chicago map, again going back to that. There are certain areas where I would have expected to see maybe a little bit more density actually. Think of a market like Oak Park, where you have an affluent suburb that's urban in nature. And I'm kind of getting back to the competitive dynamic question. Is this a situation where the carriers are bidding out kind of neighborhood by neighborhood, and there are certain areas where you haven't been able to win the business? Or is this just a matter of progression? And then also going back to the idea that in some areas the local phone company or the cable company might have existing infrastructure that would be more efficiently leveraged. Is it fair to say that in those markets where a Verizon or an AT&T has built more fiber, like a Fios type of neighborhood, that takes one potential customer out of the mix for you guys?

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: On your first question, I'd just say we're not done yet. So I think you're just seeing the progression of the build-out of wireless networks using small cells. And so we would share your view that over time, as we look at that map, we think there will be
componenttext:
On your first question, I'd just say we're not done yet. So I think you're just seeing the progression of the build-out of wireless networks using small cells. And so we would share your view that over time, as we look at that map, we think there will be an increase in density. And if you look at some of the suburbs that you pointed out, Oak Park, we would expect that there will be, over time, greater density of both fiber and nodes in those areas. On your second question -- again, this goes back to existing fiber and the capacity of that fiber to provide this kind of solution. It takes a lot of capacity of fiber. And generally speaking, the residential fiber that's used for products like you mentioned is not going to have enough capacity to handle small cells. So if it does, it's a great solution, and that would be the lowest cost alternative. But I -- typically, that is not a competitor really in our space for small cells.
Well, I just want to thank everyone for joining this morning. There may be a few folks that we weren't able to get to your questions. Obviously, feel free today to reach out to us. We'd be happy to take the questions offline and answer anything we didn't get to. We're excited about how the business is performing and what we're seeing, and look forward to catching up with you early in the New Year to talk about fourth quarter results.

headline: Crown Castle International Corp. (REIT), Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And thank you very much. That does conclude our conference for today. I'd like to thank everyone for your participation, and have a great day.
componenttext: And thank you very much. That does conclude our conference for today. I'd like to thank everyone for your participation, and have a great day.
